content:
y 1, 2014
												I was always told that F.E.A.R. was the best of the series and after playing F.E.A.R. 2 I agree, I still have to play the third one though. As I expected, F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin was a huge improvement both graphically and gameplay wise. I'd say it's still a great looking game and I could clearly notice how the gun handling was improved. I felt like on the first game the recoil was somewhat too much and needed more recoil compensation on the player end but on F.E.A.R. 2 I think they've "perfected" the shooting to better suit "casual players", while I think this is a good thing I understand if others think that the first game had more "realism", if you can call it that, to the weapons. One thing I still find to be rather "lazy" about F.E.A.R. 2  is that most of the guns are basicly just new skins of the older ones, you've got the assault rifle, the submachinegun, the "penetrator" but I gotta admit these new skins look pretty damn nice so I forgive them, one other thing, or maybe it was just me, I'm pretty sure they re-used the enemy voices and player and enemy animations from the previous game, I'm not complaining they did just the right job but I still find it lazy on the developers end. At the end of the day they did a pretty good job in keeping the shooting just as great as in the first game with improved visuals and gun handling, not to mention you can pilot Mechs on this one which I found out to present a nice variety of gameplay but, they did also put some turret segments in the game (I believe two), which I feel they didn't overdone it like some games. Still I think despite of having a great shooting experience, F.E.A.R. 2 wasn't that tense or scary as the first one, I think that's because of the improved graphics everything looks more "colourful" while in the first game everything looked kinda dark and sinister. In the end I think F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is a fine piece of work and definitely a great shooter with a nice continuation to the F.E.A.R. plot and the ending clearly gives you the clue that's more to come, I'm pretty sure you can't go wrong with F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin, either if you're looking for a great first person shooter single player experience or a first person shooter with a paranormal twist to it, F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is clearly the game for you.

												A decent sequel to F.E.A.R. The best visual design in the whole series – something more than just gray walls of underground complexes. Not much of horror in it and AI behaviour is simplistic making the enemies easy targets. However, the story is pretty good and it answers many questions I was previously confused about.What I didn't like was that it wasn't always clear where to go and that the quick save feature is removed.Nevertheless, it's a good game and I recommend it to all fans of the franchise.My overall rating: 7.5/10.Many say that F.E.A.R.3 was the worst game in the series, but I think that Project Origin is the one that deserves the third place.F.E.A.R.2: REBORN DLC: you play as one of the replica soldiers guided by Paxton Fettel, who is dead at the time  (shot by Pointman in F.E.A.R.). In terms of gameplay, Reborn is like Extraction Point, but much more sloppy. It offers only short 5 episodes (an hour of gameplay). There's not much of a story and enemy spawning and positioning isn't thought through well. It would be acceptable for an euro or two, but for 8 €, it's a steal. NOT RECOMMENDED.

content:
ber 11, 2014
												I’ve heard some people say FEAR 2 is inferior to the original game, but I actually prefer it over FEAR 1. Most notably, the graphics of FEAR 2 are greatly improved, now comparable to other Xbox 360 games/ports. There’s still an issue with default key bindings being weird compared to other modern FPS games, but you can change those easily.FEAR 2 picks up a little before the end of FEAR 1, ignoring the FEAR 1 expansion DLCs. This time your character has a name and you actually feel like part of a team, instead of just having a lot of people talk to you on the radio. However, similar to the first game you’re on your own most of the time when the bullets start flying. Your team is tasked with rescuing the CEO of Armacham Corporation, the private military contractor with more firepower than most first world nations. The Armacham leadership is trying to cover its ♥♥♥ by blaming the disaster from FEAR 1 on the CEO and sending in black ops teams to wipe out everyone and everything that could tie them to illegal activities. Not to mention *SPOILER* at the end of Fear 1, Alma was released, so she seems to have awakened all the replica forces around the city. You have a lot of visions of her wandering the halls and tearing people apart like Phoenix in the worst Xmen movie (you know which one). Like its predecessor, FEAR 2 is a first person shooter with a time slowing power that you can use to achieve tactical supremacy. The game seems a lot easier than FEAR 1 for some reason, possibly because the enemies don’t seem to have perfect aim anymore. There’re at least half a dozen new weapons, some of which are pretty cool (Lasers and electro grenades) and a pretty badass mechanized power armor that you can use to lay down the pain. Of course there are a lot of new enemies as well to soak up your bullets. This time around there are non-human enemies that have either been created by Armacham or were summoned by Alma’s psychic presence. You also need to fight some enemies with their own power armor (at least you have a missile launcher). A minor gripe of mine is that not all the weapons seem to have designated “roles.” For example the assault rifle and the submachine gun are basically the same thing. One is weaker but fires faster, that’s about the only difference. There’s also an energy weapon that is basically the same thing as the missile launcher. I won’t complain too much about it though since more variety is nice in a game with modern graphics. I wish there was better documentation of how enemy armor works. Most of the enemies seem to be wearing heavy armor. Does it randomly deflect bullets like in Rage, or just lower the received damage like in the Fallout games? The Hammerhead rifle is supposed to be great against armored enemies, but in a fast paced game like this, it’s really hard to see the difference. This is really kind of nitpicky though and it’s just something that stuck out in my mind, not a real problem.EDIT: I was wrong about the energy weapon being the same as the missile launcher. It seems to be more like a BFG 10k (from Doom) with lightning bolts shooting out of the main blast to fry people around it.Pros:+Great visuals and some unique looking monsters. The ghost summoner is pretty cool+A lot of “intel” items can be found in the game, which give you a flavor for the game world. It’s disgusting the kind of things that Armacham has been up to.+Slow-mo + sniper rifle = fun+Good story and a lot of replay potentialCons:-There’s this weird issue where each time a level loads, it seems to pause around 50% and not move until I alt+tab out of the game and go back in. I don’t know if this is specific to my computer but it also happened with my old non-steam version a few years ago.-The game has no Steam achievements despite having game achievements built right in (like 10 headshots or 10 melee kills). -FEAR 2 is kind of short. I went through it in about 6 hours on normal mode. It may take longer for someone who hasn’t played it before.Overall if you liked FEAR 1 you should like FEAR 2. I find it superior in pretty much every way. As much as I liked the first FEAR, I doubt I’ll replay it again because the outdated graphics really take away from the experience. With FEAR 2 I’ll keep it around to replay in a few months (smaller download size too). If you have this game in your inventory from the Humble Bundle, give it a try.

content:
ry 13, 2015
												For whatever odd reason, there's an awful lot of fans of the original F.E.A.R. who consider this game to be inferior.  Personally I find both games to be about equally brilliant, but let's try to analyse the possible reasons for this, shall we, and see what conclusions we come to...    Firstly, F.E.A.R. 2 is absolutely, unapologetically a more blatant "horror" game.  A large part of the charm and uniqueness of the original was the way in which it spent the vast majority of its time being a reasonably straightforward (if thoroughly excellent) first-person shooter, with only sporadic - but thereby highly effective - bits of supernatural horror creeping in; with this sequel the devs decided to turn that balance of action versus horror into a more balanced fifty-fifty split, with all manner of beasties and what-not galore now terrorising the player as well as the expected super-soldiers and giant robots.  Perhaps some naysayers felt this made the series less unique, or made the horror less "psychological" and more, well, downright physical I suppose.  I can see that point of view, honestly I can.  But...I also can't really see how they could have maintained the same super-subtle unpinning of horror without simply REMAKING the original, and this is of course where all manner of "art" / "entertainment" industry follow-ups encounter controversy; not just games, but movies, books, bands, you name it.    How many people bemoan the fact that their favourite band didn't "keep the same sound", and essentially just keep making the EXACT SAME RECORD, over and over again?  How many people believe that Aliens took the stripped-back purity of Alien and ♥♥♥♥ed it right up the pooper-shooter by turning it into a slam-bang, high adrenaline ACTION MOVIE?  Here's the thing: You can't please everybody.  EVER.  Some people want to recapture what they experienced the first time, more or less verbatim, while others want something which is sufficiently different to distinguish itself from the original product, though perhaps with just enough in common that there's some continuity maintained.  I personally belong to the latter category.  I would much rather play F.E.A.R. 2 than F.E.A.R. 1, MARK 2.  There is a difference between these two concepts, after all.    So what one needs to ask themselves, then, is what kind of person they are, or to put it another way...if you enjoyed F.E.A.R. 1 and are wondering if you will also enjoy this one, then perhaps THESE are the questions you need to ask yourself:  Are you the kind of person who enjoyed the first game, in spite of "not normally" being a fan of horror games?  If the answer is yes, then perhaps this one may go too far in the "horror" direction for your liking.  Or are you, like me, someone who actually HUMOURED the original F.E.A.R. on account of it appearing to be something of a horror game, in spite of the fact that most of the screenshots seemed to indicate otherwise?  If so, then you're probably gonna ADORE this one.  And if you're somewhere in-between the two types of people I just described, well...wait for a sale and take a punt anyway.  Why not?  You only live once.    There are other differences between the two games, of course.  This one is arguably a bit "harder", not least of all in the earliest bits where you don't even have the benefit of your slo-mo ability to make up for your ♥♥♥♥-poor marksmanship (I felt THAT one, believe me).  Your "health" isn't nearly as generous in this one, either; expect to get more-or-less "insta-killed"...a LOT.  The soldiers also don't tend to be quite as "vocal" as the earlier game...but given that the soldiers in the first game had virtual diarrhea of the mouth and a tendency to give away their location at every possible opportunity, this is arguably an improvement.  You also don't get to shoot two pistols at a time or perform those oh-so-impossible first-person jumps which suggest your character has springs instead of legs (in this one, you actually see your character's hand realistically propel him over obstacles, etc), so overall, a slightly "grittier" level of realism is definitely the order of the day here; and again, it's up to the individual whether they consider this to be a boon or an abomination.    If you ask me, this series didn't really start to go (and even then, only slightly) "downhill" until the third F.E.A.R. game; which I personally also loved to bits, though I would be inclined to agree with anyone who thinks it's the weakest of the three.  But hey, it gets harder and harder to stay "fresh" as a game series progresses, so what do people expect?  If you're happy to live your life in stasis, you have my blessing.  Me, I'll take a pinch of spice in my bowl, thanks.  Then again, I'm the kind of person who doesn't like to stay in the same boring old job for fifty solid years, either.  Each to their own, it takes all kinds to make the world, etc etc... Verdict: 10/10.

												OK sadly there is NO NEUTRAL BUTTON! this game isnt as good as FEAR 1 but it is also not that bad but suffers from many issues...... is it worth to play? yes!BUT dont forget the issues:- the story is lacking, there is nothing really extended from the first title, it's very flat sadly.... i wished much more insights- the combat in my opinion is lacking a lot! without slomo you got this time only 20% chances to win as the enemies shoot ASAP when they see you and on hard you are dead in 1-2 shots which is plain UNFAIR!!!- combat again, sadly the game is much more action oriented which wouldnt be a prob if the scheme wouldnt be always the same, enter room, slomo, shoot 3-9 enemies, a few horror scares next room and another action room- the game feels movement wise downgraded, you feel they had prioritized consoles with controllers- the level design wasnt the best in fear 1, they extended it a bit more here but sadly not made it much better...... you walk straightforward find a blocked door, walk right or left and again forward until there is something blocked, right or left and so on and on..... - the environments are boring..... the school is the highlight sadly.... - the jump scares are to 95% unscary as you always expect something next- no manual saving/quicksaving, you always know when enemies appear or the next jumpscare cause the game saves at all points before something happens.... this is taking the scariness out and the surprises. how bad devs have to be....and some more points i forgot.... it's  a good game for what it is but after 1 playthrough there is nothing left and i had to pause every hour as the game bored me fast somehow.

content:
25, 2016
												It's an average first person shooter but also a very disappointing sequel to my favourite first person shooter of all time although it would be crazy to expect something better than the original fear, i expected the game to be at least good when it released and it failed to do that too. The shooting, the weapons and the slow motion is nowhere near as satisfying or good as the original and it overall just feels like the average console shooter. The enemy ai is also nowhere near as good as the original, they feel very scripted and don't react very well to your movements. I feel like the game also struggles with the difficulty settings. Normal is way too easy and hard is just ridiculous they give the enemy amazing accuracy, they never miss a shot and you only die in a few hits. I switched to normal around halfway through the game because it just became so stupid and unfair which is a shame because the rest of the game became a breeze because there is no challenge in normal. A game should never have such drastic difference in difficulty between two side by side settings. I love challenge in games but there is a difference between challenge and unfair it's why i love the dark souls games even though they are very difficult they never feel unfair. That’s my little rant aside about difficulty settings i felt like that needed to be addressed.Some of the scares work great and some feel cheap it's very mixed. Nothing much happens throughout the story of the game which is a shame because i think that the series always had potential to tell a great story and the first game started it off really well and the concept for fear 2 is pretty good its just the storytelling isn't handled well.It sounds like i sh*t all over this game in this review but that's because it's the sequel to my favourite fps of all time so of course im going to compare it to the original and as it's own standalone game it's nothing better then the average shooter. It's only a 5 hour long game and i got sick of the gameplay just 2 hours into it. There are much better single player fps games out there, don’t bother.5/10 (Average)

content:
, 2014
												What is F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin?--F.E.A.R. 2 is the successor of F.E.A.R., an immersive psycho-horror FPS with a fantastic bullet time mechanic.----Who would most enjoy F.E.A.R. 2?--If you loved the first F.E.A.R. game, you'll most likely love this title as well. That being said, if you felt the first game was too visually dated for your tastes, or too mechanically clunky, the game has improved leaps and bounds in that department. The game also favors action packed gun-battles a little bit more heavily than the first. The tension is very slightly lighter than the first game, but it holds enough strengths to more than compensate for this.----Over-all: 80.0%As a whole, F.E.A.R. 2 is a more solid title than the first game, and will appeal to a wider audience. That being said, some of the elements that make F.E.A.R. 2 a better game as a whole, slightly subtract from the immersive experience that was  the terrifying glory of the first F.E.A.R. game.--Mechanics: 4/5The mechanics are a definiteive improvement here, over the first game. Movement in much more fluid, bullet time is possibly even more smoothly integrated, there's more interaction with the world and terrain, the AI is very well done this  time around, and as a whole, the game feels very appropriately smooth and fluid.--Experience: 4/5In the five years between the release of F.E.A.R. 1 and F.E.A.R. 2, the developers have come along way in improving the audio and visuals of the game. The game went from passibly average looking (just enough so's to not distract from the experience) to downright gorgeous. The textures are fairly average, but  the artistic embellishments in conjunction with the fantastic visual effects definitely help this game shine. The audio has also taken a massive leap, helping tie the experience together. With all that being said, the psycho-horror elements of the game have been toned down just a touch, and that in combination with a few crowd pleaser moments, and the addition of collectible bits of intel, actually subtract from the experience slightly, in my opinion. The game is still fantastically immersive, and will draw you in, unlike many other titles to date, but in comparison with the first title, I feel F.E.A.R. 2 sacrifices a chunk of it's biggest strength -- the raw gripping psycho-horror elements, for a few fun, but unnecessary scripted gun battles.Balance: 4/5--Longevity: 4/5The game is slightly shorter than the first game in the series, containing only 14 missions of roughly 30-45 minute  length each. That being said, it doesn't rely solely on the immersive experience, unlike the first game, and provides a number little bits of intel for the player to run around and find, if that's your thing. There may be room for a second playthrough with F.E.A.R. 2, between looking to find the rest of the missed bits of intel, playing through on a higher difficulty, or simply just to enjoy the beauty and fluidity of the game for second time.

content:
y 21
												Strictly inF.E.A.R.ior to the original and its expansion packs, Progect Origin is a comedy wearing the skin of a relatively drab military shooter. There are numerous things missing from it that gave the original much of its charm- the fact that when you bicycle kick someone in F.E.A.R., their head spins round and round thousands of degrees. You can't peek around corners and the stealth system is gutted in favour of run-and-gunning. Even on the hard difficulty. The voice acting is a mixed bag. Enemies are terrible and unconvincing. Your allies are pretty good, though, despite that their personalites aren't explored further than the most elementary of brushstrokes. The gunplay feels weaker, despite that enemies do explode into giblets when you fire a shotgun in their direction and I'm not sure how that's possible, but there it is. I mentioned comedy earlier: the "actual" plot- that is, the plot you get if you don't obsessively read all the pieces of intel- is a continuation from the first game, a horror-inflected, slightly dumb action-scifi. However, if you take the time to read the intel, it transforms into a sunday morning cartoon with more blood.  I realised this when I got to the elementary school level, finding a log talking about the side affects of drugs that were put in the children's food. Drugs that caused projectile vomiting. Additonally, in the school office, the parents of children report that their darlings are having nightmares about being shown violent images, strapped to chair and jabbed with needles, and that the parents were at a loss because they never showed their children anything of the sort, and are SURE that they weren't exposed to such things in school.  Even the bullet-time seems dull in comparison. What they have improved on is the degree to which the environment is degradable, and given you the chance to pilot a stompy robot. But even stompy robots cannot save this game from its sheer mediocrity. Don't waste your time. Replay the originals or watch a let's-play.

content:
y 13, 2016
												WARNING: This review will contain major spoilers of this game.Oh boy...Here comes the hate.F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is a first-person shooter with survival horror elements which is the sequel for "F.E.A.R.", a First Person Shooter with survival horror elements too, released in 2005. F.E.A.R. 2 is also made by Monolith. Starting off with this review, i think F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is a very short game. I played a few minutes in real life of this game, the rest 8 hours of gameplay wen't from one day only. Yeah it's a short game, but it's such a ride that i don't have much to say. The gameplay has been improved a lot from the first, so much that it doesn't feel like the same game, but in a good way. The storyline is ♥♥♥♥ing great in my opinion, and much better than the first, but less characters, but it think it works well that way, and better too. The voice acting is better than the first too, and let's be fair, the first game had cringe-worthy voice acting. The game contains much more scary moments and they're used much better, although annoying at some moments, while in the first, it was just the little girl going on a hall and it wasn't very scary, it was usually psychological horror. Continuing, the protagonist is badass. Sorry to say, but this'll get people murdering me and, i think Becket is more badass than Point-Man. And let's forget F.E.A.R. 3, since i don't think it's canon at all to the story. And possibly my best option to prove that this game has a better story is the ending. The ending was considered weird by critics, but i think it's a ♥♥♥♥ing epic and outstanding ending for this ride of a game. So let me tell you the ending. In the end, Becket enters the Telesthetic Amplifier, but as Stokes prepares to power up the machine, she is interrupted by Genevieve Aristide, who explains that she operated on Becket so he would serve as a lure for Alma. Instead of destroying her, Aristide plans to seal Becket and Alma inside the device together, so she can use Alma as leverage against Armacham. Stokes disagrees with Aristide's intentions, and reaches for her gun, but is shot by Artistide before she can defend herself. Stokes collapses, with her ultimate fate left unknown. Alma then appears and blows Aristide away from the Amplifier, allowing Aristide to reach the control panel and seal the chamber as the walkway retracts. Alma pays her no attention, instead focusing on Becket, who she sends into another "hallucination," where he fights off apparitions of a maddened Sergeant Keegan while trying to activate the Amplifier and destroy Alma. As Becket fights Keegan, the battle is interspersed with images of Alma ♥♥♥♥♥♥ him (I don't consider it ♥♥♥♥, but it technically is, so yeah, but it seemed pretty sexy, you have to agree). Finally, after activating the last switch, Becket escapes the hallucination to find himself sealed inside the device. The device is unsealed from the outside by Alma, who walks up to Becket and reveals she is pregnant, having ♥♥♥♥♥ him while he fought off the phantom image of Keegan. Alma takes Becket's hand and places it over her stomach, implying that the child is his. The game ends with Becket hearing the child whisper "Mommy" from inside Alma's womb. And my lord what an ending it was. Also, the graphics are great, they were amazing for 2009, and they still are great for 2016. Also, the gore is amazing. There is only one moment in the game where you control a robot mecha, which is a very good moment, which needed more sequences. The game is very glitchy at some moments by the way. So let's go for the pros and cons!A little update, i really loved the soundtrack, although it didn't really have much more and used some of the first game's tracks. Sound design is also amazing. Great gameplay obviously, too.Pros:+Outstanding ending+Great Graphics+Better Voice-Acting+Memorable characters+Weapons+Gore+Badass Protagonist+Insanely Heavy Themes (Alma's ♥♥♥♥ Frames during final boss)+Soundtrack+Sound Design+GameplayCons:-Extremely Short-Not many weapons-Glitches-Some tracks/music was re-used from the first gameOverall, F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is an amazing game, and a masterpiece, which is the best example of a sequel in a single video-game ever made.The score for F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is:10/10 ~I knew it was going to be outstanding and amazing, but not a masterpiece!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
ber 25, 2016
												Originally posted Jan 5 2012 gameaday-ish.blogspot.comStop me if you have heard this one: mute protagonist known as “Point Man” blessed with psychic/physical abilities to perceive time as a higher rate and plagued by nightmarish visions of a deranged and violent little girl shoots his way to the revelation that the bad guy, Fettlel, is in fact his cannibalistic brother. Both characters are children of the the little girl Alma, who is projecting her younger self from cryo-storage in the basement of a facility. Alma is a powerful psychic driven insane by extended experimentation and apparently, ♥♥♥♥♥ to pregnancy.That, in a nutshell, is the mythology of the original F.E.A.R. Running concurrently to the last half of the first game is F.E.A.R 2 , featuring mute protagonist “Beckett” blessed with psychic/physical abilities to perceive time as a higher rate and plagued by nightmarish visions of a deranged and violent grown woman. He shoots his way to the revelation that Alma wants him to make babies with her, if only in a psychic not physical way.F.E.A.R. 2: Fear Harder is good looking game marred by an annoying choice to run film-grain effect over the visuals. Rather than emulating Japanese horror films this aesthetic makes the game look muddy, especially when I played it on 360. The controls were sluggish as well but on PC, and with film grain off, it looks and feels like the original F.E.A.R. which is not a bad thing.Added to the mix is the ability to operate the once feared mechsuits that terrorized players in the first game. Essentially invulnerable until the power runs out, the mech sequences are explorations in destruction as hundreds of enemies are mowed into pulpy gore. Very satisfying and never outstays its welcome, unlike the main campaign.2 Fear 2 Furious addresses valid complaints about the endless monotony of office corridors that plagued the original by providing larger more open environments that act as funnels into smaller corridors. Industrial design still dominates but there are some massive setpieces that offer real scope, especially in the aftermath of the explosive conclusion of the first game.Fun and propulsive, F.E.A.R 2 The Fear Police, suffers from hindsight that the tricks of the original that thrilled and amazed have lost their sheen.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2015
												Have you ever experienced the beauty of a "fine" game? Let me elaborate: What I mean is a game that is not utterly awesome, but still does everything right. A game you pick up for a second playthrough knowing you will get nothing innovative or mind-blowing, but in spite of this, you'll still enjoy every second. Hell, after finishing, you won't rule out a third run happening in the future.FEAR 2 is this kind of game.Sure, FEAR brought some really impressive new stuff to the table, like mixing horror themes into an FPS setting, clever AI and FPS bullet time. But those were achievements introduced by the first game, and thus, FEAR 2 cannot claim them as its own. Actually, there is really nothing new in the sequel (with one notable exception, but more on that later), and stripped of the hallmarks of the series, Project Origin is a pretty standard FPS:...which is what makes it so great.A big part of why it succeeds is its pacing. FEAR 1 is a great game, without any need for great improvements. But what it lacked was proper pacing, a deficit also found in Condemned 1, another Monolith game. Many sections dragged oooon and ooooon without much variation. It was warehouse after warehouse after warehouse, and later bureau complex floor after bure- you get the point. Its scenarios simply didn't know when they wore out their welcome.FEAR 2 eliminates that weakness. Its pacing is just great. Just when a setting tends to get tedious, it switches to a new one or offers a new enemy or a nice set piece to spice things up. It never, ever gets boring, in my opinion. What's also great is that the graphics still are very good. It's a bit more colorful, but not to the excess of FEAR 3, hitting the sweet spot between the drab first game and the overkill of the third. It's another example of this "just fine" mentality I mentioned in the beginning. No, FEAR 2 won't blow you away with a great story. No, your jaw won't drop to the floor every five minutes. No, you won't marvel at game-changing innovations. Will you have a good time all the way through? Hell, yes....but my review would not be complete without addressing the one awesome new feature the game DOES introduce. You probably guessed it: Exosuit battles. There are only two sections in the campaign, but boy, are they fun! Nothing beats the feeling of gleefully raining down destruction with your gatling guns and missile launchers. Also, what could have basically have been just an overpowered reskin of the normal on-foot sections -and strictly gamplay-wise, it is - is helped so much by its presentation. You feel every step of the hulking mech when its lumbering steps shake your view, and the vision has a slight oversaturation combined with grain that completely sell the experience, A part of me wishes there would have been more of this, but on the other hand, its restrained use is another example of FEAR 2's pitch-perfect pacing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
y 13, 2016
												WARNING: This review will contain major spoilers of this game.Oh boy...Here comes the hate.F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is a first-person shooter with survival horror elements which is the sequel for "F.E.A.R.", a First Person Shooter with survival horror elements too, released in 2005. F.E.A.R. 2 is also made by Monolith. Starting off with this review, i think F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is a very short game. I played a few minutes in real life of this game, the rest 8 hours of gameplay wen't from one day only. Yeah it's a short game, but it's such a ride that i don't have much to say. The gameplay has been improved a lot from the first, so much that it doesn't feel like the same game, but in a good way. The storyline is ♥♥♥♥ing great in my opinion, and much better than the first, but less characters, but it think it works well that way, and better too. The voice acting is better than the first too, and let's be fair, the first game had cringe-worthy voice acting. The game contains much more scary moments and they're used much better, although annoying at some moments, while in the first, it was just the little girl going on a hall and it wasn't very scary, it was usually psychological horror. Continuing, the protagonist is badass. Sorry to say, but this'll get people murdering me and, i think Becket is more badass than Point-Man. And let's forget F.E.A.R. 3, since i don't think it's canon at all to the story. And possibly my best option to prove that this game has a better story is the ending. The ending was considered weird by critics, but i think it's a ♥♥♥♥ing epic and outstanding ending for this ride of a game. So let me tell you the ending. In the end, Becket enters the Telesthetic Amplifier, but as Stokes prepares to power up the machine, she is interrupted by Genevieve Aristide, who explains that she operated on Becket so he would serve as a lure for Alma. Instead of destroying her, Aristide plans to seal Becket and Alma inside the device together, so she can use Alma as leverage against Armacham. Stokes disagrees with Aristide's intentions, and reaches for her gun, but is shot by Artistide before she can defend herself. Stokes collapses, with her ultimate fate left unknown. Alma then appears and blows Aristide away from the Amplifier, allowing Aristide to reach the control panel and seal the chamber as the walkway retracts. Alma pays her no attention, instead focusing on Becket, who she sends into another "hallucination," where he fights off apparitions of a maddened Sergeant Keegan while trying to activate the Amplifier and destroy Alma. As Becket fights Keegan, the battle is interspersed with images of Alma ♥♥♥♥♥♥ him (I don't consider it ♥♥♥♥, but it technically is, so yeah, but it seemed pretty sexy, you have to agree). Finally, after activating the last switch, Becket escapes the hallucination to find himself sealed inside the device. The device is unsealed from the outside by Alma, who walks up to Becket and reveals she is pregnant, having ♥♥♥♥♥ him while he fought off the phantom image of Keegan. Alma takes Becket's hand and places it over her stomach, implying that the child is his. The game ends with Becket hearing the child whisper "Mommy" from inside Alma's womb. And my lord what an ending it was. Also, the graphics are great, they were amazing for 2009, and they still are great for 2016. Also, the gore is amazing. There is only one moment in the game where you control a robot mecha, which is a very good moment, which needed more sequences. The game is very glitchy at some moments by the way. So let's go for the pros and cons!A little update, i really loved the soundtrack, although it didn't really have much more and used some of the first game's tracks. Sound design is also amazing. Great gameplay obviously, too.Pros:+Outstanding ending+Great Graphics+Better Voice-Acting+Memorable characters+Weapons+Gore+Badass Protagonist+Insanely Heavy Themes (Alma's ♥♥♥♥ Frames during final boss)+Soundtrack+Sound Design+GameplayCons:-Extremely Short-Not many weapons-Glitches-Some tracks/music was re-used from the first gameOverall, F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is an amazing game, and a masterpiece, which is the best example of a sequel in a single video-game ever made.The score for F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is:10/10 ~I knew it was going to be outstanding and amazing, but not a masterpiece!

content:
er 5, 2016
												It's good, better than FEAR 1. Ideally play the original first so you have some idea who the heck Alma is and why everything is happening. I think enough is explained in this game that you could get the story without having played the original, but you probably want to anyway because FEAR 1 is also a really good game.I found this sequel scarier than the original. Graphics are nicer, I got higher framerates than in FEAR 1, most of the guns are better designed (the SMG and assault rifle in the original felt awful, in this installment they're both very fun to use). The developers' aptitude at storytelling has improved from where they were when they made FEAR 1. This game feels like someone made the team from FEAR 1 play a Call of Duty game and they learned about making big cinematic explosion-filled bits and scripted sequences work amazingly well.Some small technical issues, none pressing: the default keybindings are strange and I changed a lot of them; the game doesn't recognise the buttons on the side of my mouse, which is weird because FEAR 1 did (how spooky!); the lowest mouse sensitivity you can set in game is still much too high for me at 800dpi and I wound up turning my mouse sensitivity down to 250dpi in order to get a ~35cm turning circle like I prefer in FPS games.The quicksave & quickload feature is just gone but after about 15 minutes I stopped missing it and started having more fun without it. Difficulty is a little lower and gameplay feels streamlined relative to FEAR 1.Some nice technical fixes too: widescreen resolutions now work properly, some noticeable graphical defects that the original had are gone (in FEAR 1, the decal system kinda fights with the particle system, but I didn't see that happen here), framerates seem better on the same hardware.Didn't pay any attention to the multiplayer, I assume that it probably doesn't work because there's a GameSpy logo on it, but I didn't check, I don't care, I bought this only for the singleplayer game, which is excellent.

content:
er 26, 2013
												Building upon the story of F.E.A.R. core story (excluding the expansions, sadly) you pick up shortly before the end of the first title. This sequel is a bit of mixed emotions for me, personally. The game introduces a sprint as well as Iron sight aiming familiar with other modern shooters, and retains the SloMo mechanics. Story begins as a different character who had showed signs of being able to be a psychic commander not unlike Fettel and thus is thrown into a multitude of tests and challenges to confirm it. How I felt this title lost a bit of its identity by switching to another developer, as well as story not quite likable or the NPC's either. Though there are some aspects that really called true to the genre. I would get this if its on sale, a damn good sale at that.

content:
ber 18, 2016
												I'v heard a lot of things about F.E.A.R. 2I heard it was bad, good, or just okayHonestly after playing it, i'd say it's....okay.But not as good as the first F.E.A.R.Not even gonna go over the story I'l just list things that made this game good and badGOOD:~Replica Soldiers are still badass~You can drive a mech with miniguns, rockets, and thermal vision(IMO the best part about this game)~Less generic boring level design ~Flametrower ~Characters that are actually likable  That's itBAD~Shotgun is nerfed like hell. It's not OP anymore like the SPAS 12 in the first game. Also the shotguns sound weak and feel weak too. Meh~Jumpscares are more frequent ~Bigger attempt at being "scary"(But really this game's attempts at being scary with dark blood and jumpscares is laughable and made me almost fall asleep a lot~Boring underground dark science labs~Replica soldiers look badass but they sound weak, aren't as cool sounding and creepy and realistic as they were in the first game ~Alma wade is no longer a creepy adorable little girl, they decided to turn her into some naked women~Quick time events(Seriously)~Gunfights feel...less serious and dangerous ~Grenades don't explode on impact ~ShortOverall, this game is okay but it's nothing great and not as amazing as the original F.E.A.R.I never payed attention to F.E.A.R.'s storyline but I heard they screwed it up in this one so there's that. I'd recommend you stick with the first F.E.A.R. and only get this game if it's on sale(Also the ending is just...wow, pretty hard to call this a horror game after that)

r 28, 2014
												It has a much better graphic than the first. Alma is a *lot* better. But there are fewer horror scenes, and they're not so intense. I've ended it on hard level, and it wasn't hard at all. 80% of the time you'll beat all the enemies using Slow-Mo. The other 20% are real hard parts, like the Training Center, the Wagon, and the arrival at Still Island.Also, crouching doesn't save you from being shot when you're behind an obstacle. What's the point on crouching then? It is not possible to lie on the floor too.Putting these cons aside, it's a really nice game.

content:
ber 9, 2011
												F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin (F2: PO) is one of 2009's most underrated games and still continues to get a bad reputation even today. It is puzzling as to why since the story is intriguing, the gameplay is solid and the graphics are up to par in modern day gaming. F2: PO's gameplay is similar to the original F.E.A.R. where "slow-mo" is still a favored featured that never gets old in its use. F2: PO has one piece of DLC called "Reborn" that is essentially a standalone addon that hardly contributes to the story. It's disappointing that the game never utilizes SteamWorks when the in-game setup seems so close to supporting features such as Steam achievements.All in all, the game is a solid shooter with a great horror-like atmosphere that continues the story of Alma.

content:
er 24, 2013
												This recommendation is for the players that finished F.E.A.R. 1.I must admit that F.E.A.R. 2 was less interesting than the first one in many points. Even if the graphics were upgraded, and even if they understood one thing or two about level building (not making compounds too huge so the player doesn't feel like they will never get out of it).The story was less interesting because of the lack of mystery. In F.E.A.R. 1, you never truly understood what was happening, and it was this that make you continue. You wanted to know what was about to happen next. The sequel just makes you wandering throught compounds, outside environnements and an elementary school to find one people or an other. The presence of Alma is fast explained (in my opinion) so you don't need to find out anything by yourself.The horror moments, that were truly horrific sometimes in F.E.A.R. 1, are lacking solidity in Project Origin. It is way more direct, like representations of Alma attacking you, and hardly any shadows on the walls or any moments of chill throught your spine (elements that were doing really great work previously).I am still recommending it since it is a great FPS, the weapons are upgraded and less precise (in F.E.A.R. 1, the weapons were stupidly precise, the pistol was the best weapon in the game), and the environnement are really well done.

content:
er 26, 2014
												F.E.A.R 2 Project Origin, is a game where fear is really not an issue. Although one of the best shooters around, the fear factor is not the one i would appreciate in a game like this. True there are scary moments, but the game's basic core is the awesome gunfights and the bloodbath that follows. Even a scary sex hungry ghost seems kinda little, when you face her with:1 Lasers (Big deal, nobody is afraid of a big red beam that pierces everything!)2 Plasma Guns (So what if you can explode everyone with a single shot!)3 Apb Turret ( This is the reason why Arnold will hate you...)4 Mecha Armors (Cause if using an armored suit filled with machine guns and missiles cant guarantee you victory, then you are doing it wrong!!!)Also, if you ever feel like the game is really challenging, you get to use super slow motion to help you make the fights easier and more enjoyable (You get to splatter people like that and become a monster yourself ^^).The story is big and kinda generic with an ending that will make you wanna peck your eyes out, but still it was fun to play. If nothing else i got to feel like rambo ^^If you want to buy this game for a spooky ride dont, cause you will be terribly disappointed. If you on the other hand  want it for a pure shooting fest, by all means dont let it w8ing. You will love it!!!

 This game was executed pretty amazingly for an FPS horror game.  I thought this game wouldn't be as atmospheric at times in a gun game. But then there were those times where you didn't have a gun.I mostly got this game for the horror. I loved it. The school scene was absolutely the best. However, I find it was a bit too short. Obviously, there are multiple difficulties, but I don't really find any fun in playing the whole game over where the only thing different is rage factor. Of course, you can always come back to it a year later to give it another playthrough.I would definitely recommend this game. Although I did not care for the robots and all (I was mostly for the grudge girl, hehe), I still find this game worth playing if you like the horror genre. The school part was amazing. My favorite part of the game, by the way.

												The sequel to one of my favorite FPS games. This game feels like it was made to make the series more accessible for people. The guns are changed this time around to make the game feel easier when in gunfights. The A.I. is not as impressive as the first game unfortunately. It's not bad, but it has been toned down a bit. The grenade particle effects are also gone from the first game :( It's not all bad though! The long cooridor filled levels from the first game are gone. This game is changing it up every level. You even get to control an awesome mech to go down streets blowing up everything. This game is more difficult than the first one, mainly due to not being able to quicksave anymore. It has a checkpoint system this time around, which balances the game a lot better. The scares in this game feel even more terrifying this time around. The school easily has some of the scariest moments I have ever seen in a game. The new enemy types love to pop out constantly when you are least expecting it. The graphics have also got a nice upgrade. The deployable turrets were a fun new weapon, but I wish I got to use them more. The game is about 8 hours long, depending on how much you explore.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
r 18, 2015
												F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin manages to continue on with the achievement that its predecessor began; it manages to nearly perfectly combine horror and action into a single game. Though they keep the two genres seperated by making each segment devoted to one, it is done extraordinarily well and I can't think of a better game than this one to scratch both itches simultaneously.The story is enjoyable and the combat mechanics are well done as well. The variety of weaponry was an entertaining aspect of the game as well, each player might end up with a different arsenal at the end of the game based on their tastes. The horror scenes were enjoyable, and some parts were downright scary (I'm looking at you elementary school). My only real complaint with F.E.A.R. 2 was that the story seemed to get a little slow right around the middle. Once I returned to the game after a short break and powered through another level, it got very exciting, though, and I'm very glad that I kept moving forward.I recommend this game to all fans of FPS and horror. The game was enjoyable on both sides of that. If you are a fan of the original, definitely pick this one up as well!

content:
r 18, 2014
												F.E.A.R. 2 is a First Person Shooter Horror game.Also check my first review about F.E.A.R. 1 since this review is not as extensive as usually.This is because my F.E.A.R. 1 review already has most of the aspects in it. Also positive/negative wisely most is just the same.It doesnt continue where F.E.A.R. ended as some might think.It tells the story after the explosion from a different perspective.You are Becket. Just like in the first game you dont know who you are, except your name and your job.You are hunted by Alma again. But why is Alma mostly after you? What does she want from you?There is more than you might think. And why the hell does a guy called Snake Fist contact you?All this you have to figure out in F.E.A.R. 2.Game is mostly the same compared to the first F.E.A.R. except that some gameplay mechanics were updated like your hud. You wear glasses now which display your hud also your flashlight has no limit now. The graphics were updated just like the engine. Actually it looks very fancy. You can sprint now too.Game is still scary, even if some persons say its not as scary as F.E.A.R. 1.Cant really agree with this. The halucinations are even better now. They look amazing.The scene in the school is the best. I dont say anything more, I try to avoid spoilers in my reviews.And now you get actually directly attacked by Alma. You have to defend yourself when she approaches you.But actually she doesnt seem to want to kill you as other persons in the game tell you.Or maybe she is impressed that you are the only one who can resist her attacks.There is something more, something pretty surprising. But you will get this after finishing the actual game.Multiplayer is down because of Gamespy being dead.The actual playtime is around 7 hours for the campaign.There is also a DLC available but im reviewing this seperately.Positive:- Bullet time- Good Story- Big amount of options ingame- Alma is one of the best game characters ever- No health regeneration!- Somewhat good graphics (2009)- Great play with the dark and shadows- More modern feeling- Good and fitting unique soundtrack- Great freaking hallucinations!- Some nice environments, especially more compared to the first game- Good Enemy AI- Shooting is a lot of fun- One of the best and most surprising videogame endingsNeutral:- German Steam store version cutNegative:- Some questionable keys like shift for zooming with the weapon... Changeable- Multiplayer dead, gamespy downReplayability: MediumFor me this game was just as good as the first part. In fact I actually thought its even better, slightly. Mostly because it feels more modern and doesnt have problems with modern systems.I personally would rate it with 9/10 points.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
2, 2014
												F.E.A.R. was an incredible game with an AI the likes of which had never been seen. It had a decent enough of a storyline that acted as a great vehicle for getting to explore a very Akira-esque underground facility. It's still visually stunning to this day (I played it a few months back). All of those traits are dumped for F.E.A.R. 2. An alarming percentage of the enemies will stand off in the distance as you shoot them repeatedly in the head. If they aren't standing perfectly still, they will abandon cover and run straight at you. The storyline  is much more limited than the first. While I think the J-horror jump scares of the original were pretty dumb, the story was at least compelling enough to create a real sympathy for Alma. Alma plays a minor role at most in Project Origin, with the devs perferring you to have a strong bond with your mindless, soulless teammates while giving you no reason to feel connected to them except by telling you how close you all are. All of the imagination that went into the original facility is gone here. The sense of scale has been scaled down, if you will, to a couple of small buildings and an itty bitty underground lab.Everything about it feels more like an ambitious yet terrible expansion pack than a real sequel. If you adore the original as much as I do, I would definitely suggest you just appreciate it and it's second expansion pack, Perseus Mandate, and leave F.E.A.R. 2 alone as to not spoil your fondness for the original.

content:
5, 2014
												The consolized follow-up to the classic action-horror shooter. It does not live up to the intensity of its predecessor due to its lack of soul and innovation.Pros* High production values for the graphics, the voice acting and the quality assurance* A few urban or underground setpieces are genuinely cleverCons* The horror sequences are not scary and the gunplay is far from being as satisfying as in the first game* The level design is unimaginative and the story doesn't pull you in – you have to wait half of the (short) game's length for anything remotely interesting to happenThe game is less surprising than the two expansion packs for the original game. Even if you are a fan of F.E.A.R. the revamped visual design is so different this game may not even work out for you.

number of helpful: 16 of 31 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Really average shooter , Which  is a shame because F.E.A.R and its expansions were amazing . The game suffers from a lot of problems . They moved from a manual save to a checkpoint system which is terrible because they  are really badly placed. Enemies spawn out of thin air . The AI isn't any where near as good as F.E.A.R . The enemies often run out of cover , and don't communicate with each other  . The guns feel like pea shooters , and the difficulty is all kinds of unbalanced . Either the enemies are total push overs or they're pulling off crazy headshots from across the map . There an absolutely stupid amount of post processing effects in the game ,so many that actually has a negative effect on the gameplay . The only redeeming feature is the kickass mech  but you only get to play with it in two sections.  Its not the worst fps I've ever played , but Its a poor sequel l to one of the greatest games ever made.

content:
er 22, 2014
												High quality console shooter. Graphics are nice, sound is present, there is even some kind of story. HOWEVER THIS IS NOT A F.E.A.R. GAME AT ALL. All they have to do is to copy the first game and polish graphics - bam, another award-winning shooter. Instead of that devs decided that players like being tacticool - press ACTION TO CREATE A BAD COVER. Walking robot parts are plain boring - w+m1, stop to regen. Weapons feel light (probably because of reloading animations, especially sniper rifle which is made of paper. Speaking of sniper rifle - you can quickscope). At least the enemies seem to be as smart as before (on hard). Unfortunately they are just cannon fodder - walking robot and turret parts will make you yawn. Btw right before the last interval you'll be forced to sit behind the turret to shoot enemies while listening to some generic rock music ( Snake Fist (Instrumental) - look it up on YouTube). Oh, and your dudebro ally will be shouting some nonsense - like I am in CoD or something. Lack of manual saving, weak story, short duration, casualisation - all of this killed the spirit of F.E.A.R. The game is good as a console shooter, I cannot deny that. It is just not the game I was expecting.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2012
												After the stellar FEAR, I was interested to play FEAR2 and see how it would compare.  One of the main issues in FEAR was the lack of variety in the environment. This is thankfully fixed in FEAR2! With varying environments such as schools, clubs and hospitals. Also the fun slow motion combat still remains intact thankfully. Also the environment graphics and paranormal effects are really well done. However the horror is still the same, maybe creepy sometimes but never really gets scary, even with obligitory cheap jump scares! The story is bland and the ending is not only really dumb but exposes plot holes in the story. Also the game has been made rather mainstream in comparision to FEAR, with no save anywhere features, a focus on large set pieces and lots of quick time events which is a shame. But it's still a fun game if you're a fan of the FEAR series and of FPS's in general, hell you could do alot worse anyway!

content:
27, 2015
												FEAR 2. In some ways, I enjoy this game. It's got elements of the original FEAR that I enjoy, but it's also got plenty I don't. Changes in the health system and the way armor and health works makes the game more artificially difficult because your character cannot carry 10 health kits and cannot take more than a single shotgun blast (From long range it seems sometimes). Which is annoying because FEAR 2 has automatic shotguns. It's AI is also not quite as intelligent, but it does have elements that seem to work with it. Mostly I have to say the story is the main problem with it. FEAR 1's story was well told, through a mixture of speech and moment elements. You got a sense of Alma's motives by exploring the environment, watching her actions, and the like. But FEAR 2 seems mostly about just shaming Armachan and other stupid things. I dunno. It's just not as interesting as FEAR 1 in its story. Ultimately, skip this and FEAR 3: Clive Barker's Jericho.

content:
r 18, 2015
												This is the second episode in the F.E.A.R. trilogy, and a bit of a disappointment. If you've played FPS like Half-Life 2 or Doom 3, nothing about the gameplay will enthrall you. The story is even sillier than the first part, F.E.A.R., and ends most timidly and laughably, especially after subjecting you to quite an intense gunplay barely 5 minutes earlier. The game just can't make up its mind whether the chief villain, Alma, is a victim of a secret military experiment, an alien, or a ghost. How in the hell can hallcinations eat away one's health? But they do in this game. Go figure.Just like the first game, you are made to shoot your way through several office complexes, underground research facilities, and subway tunnels. There's nothing to do in the game except kill, kill, kill, the waves of enemies obstructing your progress. The game relieves you of all the brain-work and figures your way forward for you. Enemy AI, while not pathetic, is predictable and makes the gameplay boring after a while. You can foretell 8 times out of 10 where the enemy is hiding, from where it is going to emerge, and your best hiding spots. Environs and locations have dull colors and textures and look depressing. One may wonder what the 12GB download size of this game went into since the game is easily completable within 15 hrs. Background music is grating and a nuisance. During gun battles, it prevents you from hearing enemy chatter & movement, and is best turned way down. The sound-mixing too is completely screwed-up. While in the first game, all six channels of the soundtrack worked well and enabled one to ascertain the direction of enemy's approach from the sound of footsteps or radio chatter, sound in this game doesn't seem to have been configured for multi-channel setup. In my experience, a well-configured multi-channel soundtrack is absolutely critical in clearing major gun battles in any intense shooter by assisting in effectively taking out the enemies sneaking up on you. I hope sound mixing engineer was fired for not doing his job properly. Horror element is childish and the game uses cheap jump-scare tactics to shake you up. Difficulty levels are once again messed up, as they were in the first game. HARD setting is hardly hard and difficult to tell apart from the normal setting except for sniper fire and grenades which kill you in one instance. In fact, I found HARD setting easier than the NORMAL setting, but it may be because I played on HARD setting after having played the game on NORMAL, therefore having the advantage of knowing maps and enemy movement in advance. There are other minor flaws and irritants in the game design that further sour the experience, such as, grenades bouncing around like tennis balls, inability to load only the last save point and not the older ones, etc. Now that I've ripped the game apart, let me mention that the game is not too bad a product on a stand-alone basis, and a typical FPS lover can have fun with it. It's really in comparison to other FPS on the market that it appears dim-witted. Coming from a major studio, one expects a game to deliver a unique and unforgettable experience. Isn't that why we all play video games--because they 'virtually' put us in places & situations where we won't ever find ourselves in real lives? That's why at least I play 'em. This game does that alright, but via an unimaginative design and in a bland style.I know I won't be playing this game ever again. I also know I'd have at least 3x more fun repeat-playing any game of the Half-Life or Bioshock or Far Cry franchise.Game played smoothly without a stutter (except freezing twice during the entire gameplay and subsequently self-correcting on its own) on a Win 10 machine and a GTX 960 OC card.RECOMMENDED to newbie FPS players. For veterans, AVOID. 6/10.

content:
r 27, 2016
												First of all a short FEAR 1 review, because it's not possible on Steam to do so apparently. It still runs reasonably well and the gunplay is extremely satisfying. Story is good too and there's not really any other "horror" shooter out there, so there's that. The game drags on a bit, however, and the 2 expansions don't offer much new, apart from a few weapons and enemies. The saddest thing about Fear is its lack of environmental variety. Everything is pretty much grey and happens indoors.Now on to Fear 2. Armor and health are still the same, though you can now only carry 3 med kits which restore full life, and armor instantly replenishes it to 100% as well.The gunplay is still satisfactory, but somehow FEAR 1 did it better imho. I can't put my finger on it though.Gun and enemy variety is imho still the same as in FEAR 1, even worse. There are regular soldiers with different weapons, heavy armored soldiers, power armored soldiers and heavy power armored soldiers (mini bosses kinda). Apart from that we have the assassin again, some form of mutant leaper and ghosts. Oh and you encounter a flame thrower guy...twice. Nothing that sticks out really. Weapon variety is the same. There's no new weapon in the game, really. True, you get a sniper rifle, but then FEAR 1 had a similar weapon. And there is 1 new energy based weapon, but that's it.They've also removed some features like leaning around corners. However, you can sprint now, but omg is that spring horrible. Slow Motion is now an automatic cheat mode, because it highlights all enemies and really slows them down. FEAR 1 was fairer imho. I also didn't use the slow mo in F1 quite as often as in this game. It wasn't that powerful imho.What's better is that headshots are finally registered as increased damage. In F1 the first soldier in a group would instantly die to 1 shot, while the others took quite a lot more punishment, no matter if you shot them in the head or not. Enemies still don't die of a single headshot (apart from sniper rifle), but that's ok. They are less bullet spongy overall.On the other hand, in F1 you knew you would come upon a group of soldiers. Maybe a squad of 5 or so. Here you eliminate 5 enemies, all you can see. You move forward, and suddenly you are surrounded by another 5 enemies. It feels a bit like a shooting gallery with enemies constantly spawning. Quantity instead of quality though. The AI is doing ok.Graphics are of course better, but for some reason the sound is really muzzled, even with everything set to max and my speakers louder than usual the game just didn't feel "ballistic". Maybe that's why F1 had better gun fights, they just sounded more brutal. The weapons in Fear 2 kinda sound subdued.But at least the environments are pretty different this time around.The game gets very repetitive, however. There are rarely too many different objetives or levels after you're about halfway through and it simply revolves around running from fight to fight. There are also a few collectibles in game that give a bit of background information, but the phone calls in F1 were vastly superior. These are just text documents this time around. Also, no more health powerups, just stamina.Particularly fun are the heavy power armor sections. You don't just have to fight those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, no, you can use one yourself. Twice. Although you are pretty much invincible.There are also 2 on rails sections. Those are terrible. I don't know why they're in. Also the "tram" section of the game is just tedious.Oh, and no more manual saving (big no no) and also a permanent flash light now. Does not run out of battery and has to be recharged, which does take away the edge. Also enemies don't seem to really respond to the flash light that much anymore.It's not a terrible game, just not as good as FEAR 1 imho and if you can't live up to your predecessor I have to give a thumbs down. Also over fairly quickly. I doubt you will take longer than 8 hours even on a higher difficulty. The addon is a waste of money, but I think it's included in most bundles now anyway, so eh. It's about half an hour of gunning down more enemies. With the same weapons. And you learn a tiny bit more about Fettel.

content:
er 7, 2014
												I want to write a review of this game because I think everyone need to know what will get when play this game.I played F.E.A.R., F.E.A.R.:Extraction Point and F.E.A.R.:Perseus Mandate a few weeks ago. I love them. They scared me a few times and I enjoyed it. The story (specially the F.E.A.R. and the Extraction Point) was really good. The mixture between scares and fights was really good, and the notes on the story gave you a good perspective about what was happening. So, with that in mind, I began to play F.E.A.R. 2.Oh, what an error.The game is practically everything shooting, shooting, and more shooting. There are a few little low quality scares in the first half of the game, but the next hours is only bullets for everyone in really big (and boring) combats.The notes are practically irrelevant. Some little details, or things you really pass to know.Also, the story is... not interesting at all.And then, I finished it. So, I played my recently bought (in the Halloween Steam Sales) F.E.A.R. 2 DLC. It couldn't be worse.Oh, yes, it can.There's practically no story. Only more bullets for everyone. There are no scares. Only guns.And the final combat was really boring.Summing up, the only good points of the game were seeing (only a few times in the first half) little Alma with good graphics and the possibility to pilot (but only two times in F.E.A.R. 2 and once in the DLC) an armored robot. No more, no less.That's all about this game.

content:
21, 2015
												Dull, repetitive, and uninteresting.I had little expectations when I started playing F.E.A.R. 2, but i had thought the series sounded interesting and wanted to play the first game when it came out. Playing this game was still a disappointment. The levels were dull and uninteresting in design and layout. The characters all dull and two-dimensional, not to mention very stereotypical. What could be claimed as a plot and setting were poorly presented, badly paced and left me wanting it over not even half-way through. There was no scariness, no tension. Jump scares were continually accompanied by violin screeches, and were ineffective. The ending was disturbing, and didn't make much sense until I looked at some videos on youtube after about it. Even then it feels like it was mostly disconnected from the rest of the game. The possible attempt at adding atmosphere by having the HUD flicker was very annoying, bothered my eyes and since it didn't extend to anything besides the player's HUD and flashlight it felt like it was meant to punish the player more than be atmospheric.Playing through on normal difficulty I found there were more than enough health and armor pickups to almost be constantly at full health. Weapons were frustrating because of the number found in game, the limit to the number able to be carried and their blandness, none really stood out for power or accuracy or usefulness beyond what ammo was most plentiful. At least one weapon had no other ammo besides the 5 shots it had when given. Grenades felt weak and mostly useless. (shock grenades were the only type consistently useful).The boss fights were moderately interesting. The AI was interesting, the use of cover was fine, but the randomly running between cover spots, or the often indecisive movement of the AI trying to choose a spot to run to for cover were a pain. The powered armor sequences were even more linear and dull, and there was a greater tempation to not use the armor when available to try and give myself something challenging. I also went through most of the game without using the bullet-time ability very much. It didn't really seem needed for very much. There is also only about 6-7 different types of enemies, most of which are similar soldier types.

content:
ber 23, 2015
A mediocre game that simply isn't worth the time when there are so many good games out there.  
The shooting is unsatisfying, with boring enemies, dissapointingly vanilla weapons and an over reliance on the Slow-motion gimick to the exclusion of almost anything else.  The level design is completely on-rails and almost exclusively takes place in dark, ruined corridors.  The horror aspect is tame and one never truly feels that a malevolent psionic god-child poses any real threat to them.  The story, what little of it is presented is full of bland, boring characters whose only purpose seems to be to die horribly moments after the narrative focuses on them making it hard to get invested in the tale. Despite this, it's a functional game but one that only too well shows it's console origins and suffers horribly from a lack of ambition.

y 9, 2014
												Take what was the first game, throw some graphics on it, mix in some qte's, make the levels smaller, throw in some weapons that aren't that great and nerfed (cept the sniper), tons of non-interactive cutscenes, shorten the gameplay, some parts where you can control a mech, dumb down the scary sequences, top it off with a lackluster story and an endgame challenge (no boss fights here!) that is as cheap and shallow as what the whole of this game feels towards anyone who has ever played the first game. number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												F,E,A,R, 2 is a two steps forward, two steps back kind of sequel. On one hand we have better looking levels, (Fear 1 was just grey office buildings) more variety (more weapons, more varried levels) and better graphical quality. But on the other hand, we have AI that are not as good, this is probably because people got sick of getting lost in Fear 1 because of all the different doorways to an area (which allowed the AI to be more tactical and flank). The gunplay is also lacking, weapons are more varried, yes, but they have much less recoil. However, they still have good impact, bullets ripping through enemies looks arguably better and because they reduced recoil you spend less time in bullet-time mode because you needed to do that A LOT in F.E.A.R. 1.As for the scare factor, it can sometimes be scary but don't let that discourage you if you are interested in this game. The scares serve more as an adrenaline booster than to leave you with absolute horror.This game is one of my favorite FPS of all time mainly because of how varried it is, It has a lot better pacing then the previous games and more variety then I see in most big budget titles. I give it a full reccomendation if you like FPS.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 20
												To start off this review I just want to say that I loved the original fear. It is probably my most favorite shooter of all time. But this game is a mistake that should have never been made. In the original fear one of the most amazing things it had to offer was the AI. Instead of the enemies running into you like in any other generic shooter, FEAR's AI was so smart that the enemies will try and flank you and interact as a team so well in ways that will blow your mind. However in the sequel the AI has been dumbed down so much that the devs looked at it and made it work in the worst way possible. The way the AI actually works in this game is that they will camp behind a wall where they've already seen you waiting for you to come back in a room and for some reason deal a RIDICULOUS burst of damage that when without armor and full health will kill you instantly before you even know what the hell just happened. And on top of being programmed so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly some of the enemies become an absolute bullet sponge that will take 4 shots from the shotgun to kill. Everything else in this game is just equally as bad-the new quick-time events, the pistol is now completely useless and never worth using, oh and the story. The story is as much as a joke as everything else exept that the story accompanied with everything that's bad in the game will turn your experience into an absolute mental asylum that will make you go insane and never want to play a video game again. Small little spoiler: One of the idiots in the main plot of the story's name is "Snake Fist" that is someone who somehow knows what everything is going on in the setting. If the name "Snake Fist" didn't make you gag or cringe or whatever there's still much more brain devoid garbage that lies further into the story. In conclusion I'd like to say that F.E.A.R 2 is an absolute failure and should never be played because of how it will drive you into a mental asylum. That's all folksTL;DRThis game is a horrible mess never play it

er 5, 2013
												A Linear, on-rails shooter that tries very hard to bring horror and symbolism to first person shooters. It stumbles upon itself and seems confused as to whether it wants to be an action game, a cleverly crafted horror game, or a jumpscare simulator. The shooting mechanics are stale, the guns feel like toys, the characters aren't very likable and the plot makes little to no sense.There are worst shooters out there, but there shouldn't be any reason to settle for this either.

content:
er 24, 2013
												SingleplayerYeah I just finished the story and I have to say, good job Monolith Studios. This sequel was a worthy continuation of the F.E.A.R. story. People who played the first part (as I did) will feel like they are coming home. If you played the first part everything will be familiar and you know most of the enemies and you will know most of the weapons that are available. The graphics are a bit outdated, but WHO cares when the story is awesome. I have to admit, Almas jumpscares couldn`t get me as bad as in the previous F.E.A.R. game. Because they were basically the same....But yes, I`ve seen parts in the game that made me really smile and think: Holy crap this is nicely done (school part) and some horror-movie directors should take this as example and maybe make better movies. But yes, thats another story. All in all I recommend this to ALL F.E.A.R. fans and people who dont mind about graphically outdated, brutal shooter-action, which this game can deliver easily. Multiplayer*Dead* Sad but that is the truth. Wanted to give it a go, but there is not one server online. Checked it multiple times.

content:
er 7, 2013
												While the original FEAR managed to make you scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at times with just the right amount of visuals, FEAR 2 kind of fails there. Yes, it's scary, but when what I'd assume was supposed to be the biggest random scare moment comes attached to a QTE and pops up again and again throughout the game, you quickly get over the scare factor and just get annoyed at the QTE breaking the flow of the game.Visualy, it looks damn good, the story is decently written and the enemy AI lives up to the hype. However, you spend the early part of the game without the "Bullet Time" from the first FEAR, since this is not a direct sewual, but a story that takes place somewhat parallel the the first, so you are not playing the silent protagonist from the first game.Honestly, this game was good when it was released, but now it falls into the "decent" catagory. At the current price it's worth it if you're a fan of the FEAR series like I am.

content:
y 30, 2014
												This game has enough reviews already taken its age. So I'll just say this: it's a hell of a game! ... most of the time.I really enjoyed the first 3/4 of it. It had a nice pacing, alternating between an hostile and creepy atmosphere and a normal fps.That last 1/4 of it was... more of an on-rails fps, unfortunately. Very few "horror-ish" scenes, which made for a more generic experience. Also, the difficulty spiked, becoming far harder out of nowhere.But, it was definitely worth it for the rest of the game. The designers knew how to get the player uncomfortable, in a very good way. There were memorable situations. There were a few jumpscares, but they were well placed, so that's not an issue.It's not a very scary game, but it had its moments. Quality over quantity. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a creepier fps. But, it falls for some of the modern shooter trappings closer to the ending, unfortunately.Also, sound and visual design was great! This game still looks good, and sounds even better, even after 5 years.
