content:
y 2, 2013
												F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin:Intro:Alma is back in the second game of F.E.A.R. named F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin. If you enjoyed the first game this will be worth your money.Do not expect this game to be a better version of the original game – there is no such a thing!This game got some improvements compared to the first F.E.A.R. game, but a lot of downsides as well.Graphic, controls, performance, & sound:Graphic: The overall graphics got enchanted to look shinier and more modern - I especially like the blood which looks a lot more like liquid compared to the first one, plus an added effect, bodies also drop organs sometimes when they explode - however I miss the random body part (like a arm or a leg) that could fly off into the distance from the first F.E.A.R. game. Generally effects like: explosions, bullet impacts on surface or ground and shotgun bursts, looks absolutely terrible in my option, its way to white/yellow and without any detail, looks like something done in a hurry and is very a shame!Controls: All controls can be customized and is a great way to use your own key liking. Also a new thing in F.E.A.R.2 is the sprint mechanic, however one thing I didn’t like is that you cannot toggle it on and off; if you toggle on your sprint it’ll last as long as the sprint meter is up, that can lead to awkward situations where you just need to stop up in a hurry even a half second faster count, if trying to avoid incoming attacks or taking cover.Performance: I haven’t had any performance issues at all running the game maxed out, always on a steady/capped 60 fps even on a low-end CPU and a small amount of ram.Sound: The sound effects work very well to create the dark and creepy atmosphere this game is going for. A common thing in the F.E.A.R. series is a high pitch noise whenever a scare is coming up, if I like it or not is the question, one could say it is hard to be taken off guard with such a mechanic.  Horror:Scares in the world of F.E.A.R. is a great thing, and I like that Alma appeared this much in the second game, however, the same kind of scares appeared way too often which only made it annoying and predictable.Asides from the point on scares (jump scares) this game has a surprisingly large focus on the small and creepy details of the horror genre, if one is to explore around like I did on my second walkthrough. I found a lot of things that I missed blindly first time, simply because I didn’t notice it, and that’s something I admire of a horror game. “You may not even realize they could be watching yah, aye?”Artificial Intelligence:The AI replica soldiers got a lot dumber compared to the first F.E.A.R. (or its expansions), their behavior is too monotonous, which makes killing them a little tedious and like a routine you go through. Their awareness is also not working like it should: Moving from floor 1 and up in the right side by the stairs, the AI’s standing on the left side of floor 2 spotted me, because I had a flashlight on (they yelling: we got a flashlight over here) – even though a wall was blocking their sight on floor 2. Uh makes sense? I think not!Overall:Even though this review may sound rather critical and demeaning, I do not mean any of it in a negative manner, and the game does have its good moments. This review is simply based on my own perspective, from my experience and thoughts about the game and I’ll certainly recommend it if you enjoyed the original F.E.A.R. game or its expansions and couldn’t get enough.The playtime value is about 12 hours.F.E.A.R. 2: Reborn:A very small DLC to the original F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin.I am not very impressed by the DLC due to the leak of new content.One thing the DLC did provide was some missing information for the 3rd F.E.A.R. game, but that alone isn’t worth getting the DLC for, in my option.Very low playtime value, I completed the DLC in less than an hour.

												Worse than the predecessor in nearly every way. Since the armor takes forever to deplete if you even try to take cover, the game is way too easy. The weapons aren't nearly as fun to use as before and cool stuff like dual wielding pistols or the cool lighting gun have been removed. In fact, the game feels dull pretty much all the time. It feels like playing a generic shooter with slowdown mechanic and a random girl walking around.Not to mention that this game plus the DLC took just as much time for me to beat as Extraction Point expansion for the first Fear, and unlike Extraction Point, this game isn't worth replaying because the combat is so forgettable. Just stick to the first Fear and pretend this one doesn't exist.

												I just finished it and i think its a good game. the sounds are nice, it has some creepy moments and also some funny easter eggs (During Interval 3, when Becket enters the crane control room where Colonel Vanek is first seen taunting the player, there is a readout on the control panel that reads, "More dots, more dots, come on, more dots, ok, stop dots."), the level design is nice. well the graphics are okay. the animations look realistic, exept the animation of shot enemys, they sometimes just dissapear or beam to the ground after bullet impact.the main game is a bit too easy in my opinion - you can just be rushing without dying a single time, on hard difficulty. the reborn dlc has a few more enemys and is a bit more of a challenge.all together its about 7,5 hours of fun and shouldnt be missing in your games collection.

content:
2014
												F.E.A.R. 2 is a big step up from the first game in many ways. It provides a more cinematic look as opposed to the first game's rough, arcade style. It's considerably scarier, shifting some of its focus towards more tangible horrors and fine-tuning its brand of psychological horror. It's prettier, with high-poly models, realistic animations, and a whole range of pretty shaders. F.E.A.R. 2 is a better game than its predecessor. It's a game that has finally learned how to scare you, even if that means abandoning pure psychological horror for a more threatening approach. It's not a game riddled with jump scares either. While the slow-mo takes off some of the horror edge, encounters with the new enemies and navigating the new setpieces is very frightening.As usual, the game's plot seriously sags in the middle, but I think the only real problem with the game is that the ending is so abrupt and disappointing. There's almost no buildup, and the final fight of the game is far too easy and builds almost no tension. And then, it abruptly ends. The game itself is short, which gives the game no room for pacing aside from moving between horror bits, action bits, and story bits. In fact, aside from the very ending, there's nothing new brought to the table here, story-wise. Just some backstory you don't need to know or could have already picked up from the first game.Despite F.E.A.R. 2's lackluster plot, short length and abrupt ending, it's a good game. The combat is as fluid as ever, the game feels more broad with its increased horror and cinematics, and the visuals and sounds have been spit-shined for a nice finish. If plot isn't your thing and you just want a good, tense, shooter, then F.E.A.R. 2 will deliver that and then some.

												It was very hard to enjoy FEAR 2 because: level design was very cooridor-like for most of the game same object (e.g. piano - why would there be 5 grand pianos in the same school??) repeated multiple times throughout the entire game, making environments look unrealistic. 												F.E.A.R. 2Got this  game a while ago, but idk why im waiting til now to write a review, not like anyone reads this ♥♥♥♥ anyways.Ah well i got half a 40 of bud and some pringles so ima stick it out til they run out.So this game is the sequel to F.E.A.R. (Well no ♥♥♥♥ right?) Lemmme finish you impatient ♥♥♥♥♥♥.The first FEAR ends with a huge explosion, and alma climbing into your chopper to scare the ♥♥♥♥ out of you for one last time and get the final "Wtf is going on" from your lips.This game starts off in an APC all casual like and leads you along a nicely done kinda intro area if you will.then it proceeds to kinda make you jump outta your seat a little with a whole new set of tricks to scare the living s**t out of anyone with their eyeballs stuck to the screen.Then ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan, and turns into a beautiful action/horror game where your kicking a s  s and taking names all across the board. Slo Motion make the action so much sweeter in this game from simple gunfights to full blown wars with whatever the hell you feel like.All the while your taking ♥♥♥♥ from noone on you high horse of dousche baggery, the game places little tidbits of story info and background data alll over the place for you to look at, ingest, speculate about all of the crazy s**t happening to your character. The enviornments are heavily detailed and are able to be interacted with making no two firefights truly the same, and with a huger arsenal of brutal weapons ranging from simple pistols to high penetrating nailguns. This game truly shines in its one of a kind momennts where the action breaks and the player finds themselves isolated in very odd and peculiar places. Then the real fun begins.I give it an 8/10And this ♥♥♥♥ is cheap as dirt too

er 10, 2012
												F.E.A.R was one of the most terrifying, beatuiful, and technically competent games I had played back when it came out.F.E.A.R 2 pushes the JupiterEX engine to new (beatiful) heights, while at the same time losing some things that made F.E.A.R 1 seem so mind blowing. The environmental destructibility is far toned down. However, there are tons more fluid movements and more scripted ways to interact with the environment. I think this iteration is more immersive, if less impressive visually.Gameplay wise, it is pretty fluid and slick. Very enjoyable for a budget price. The expansion is short and doesn't really bring much to the table. However, the core game expands the story nicely and gives us a bit more insight into Alma. The voicemails are gone, which I find a huge regression/let down. We do have other text documents to read however.Weapons feel good, enemies are powerful, it looks and sounds great. What isn't to love?

content:
y 5, 2013
												Pretty damn good game. Short but sweet. While not entirely bug-free, it's a lot more polished than its prequel. The game also seems to be a bit more clever with its scares, making the scary bits a lot more enjoyable.The level design is on par with the original FEAR, though a little more varied. Paths to objectives are unrealistically complex, but fun nonetheless.Combat is different. The AI seems to be less intelligent but can handle more damage and is more accurate when shooting. Some enemies towards the end can take a bit too much damage to my liking, but not to the point where it gets frustrating. There is no more peeking from cover, meaning you can't fight the same as you did in the original FEAR. On the other hand, it's much easier to flank enemies than it is in the original. While I prefer the original combat and enemies, I don't dislike the ones in FEAR 2. With the exception of fighting monsters, that is.The game's biggest fault, is that they wanted to include more enemy variety and ended up with some complete BS monsters. There's the fast-but-weak creepy-crawly monsters that are just an annoyance because they do so little damage but are hard to hit and the puppeteer monster that takes a ♥♥♥♥♥on of damage, keeps running away and has the most annoying attack in the world. The latter monster is challenging, sure, but also a real chore.The story is pretty fun, until you start to think about it and you discover some things that don't quite make sense (or aren't adequately explained, at least). The original game was the same, though.Both FEAR and FEAR 2 are must-plays.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
17, 2011
												The game is much maliged by long term fans, though I don't really understand it. The game has all the essentials that the first one did. It  may not seem to push the envelope technologically as its predecessor did, but  FEAR 2 isn't a slouch in that regard either. In all, I enjoyed the act of PLAYING much more with this sequel. FEAR was a great game, and it wowed us all with its chip melting tech, but it also felt flimsy at times, almost like being in a diarama, however beautiful. FEAR 2 is solid, like a rock. It has weight, and more importantly, it has colour. What was excised from the formula has, I think, done more to strengthen the gameplay than weaken it. And it's ironic that critics bemoan the perceived loss of certain atmospheric and narrative elements in favour of increased action. Let's face it, FEAR was never 'scary'. It was tense, sure, but Condemned - THAT'S a scary Monolith game. The FEAR series has always been primarily for the action, and this second game delivers.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2013
												Pretty damn good game. Short but sweet. While not entirely bug-free, it's a lot more polished than its prequel. The game also seems to be a bit more clever with its scares, making the scary bits a lot more enjoyable.The level design is on par with the original FEAR, though a little more varied. Paths to objectives are unrealistically complex, but fun nonetheless.Combat is different. The AI seems to be less intelligent but can handle more damage and is more accurate when shooting. Some enemies towards the end can take a bit too much damage to my liking, but not to the point where it gets frustrating. There is no more peeking from cover, meaning you can't fight the same as you did in the original FEAR. On the other hand, it's much easier to flank enemies than it is in the original. While I prefer the original combat and enemies, I don't dislike the ones in FEAR 2. With the exception of fighting monsters, that is.The game's biggest fault, is that they wanted to include more enemy variety and ended up with some complete BS monsters. There's the fast-but-weak creepy-crawly monsters that are just an annoyance because they do so little damage but are hard to hit and the puppeteer monster that takes a ♥♥♥♥♥on of damage, keeps running away and has the most annoying attack in the world. The latter monster is challenging, sure, but also a real chore.The story is pretty fun, until you start to think about it and you discover some things that don't quite make sense (or aren't adequately explained, at least). The original game was the same, though.Both FEAR and FEAR 2 are must-plays.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
y 1, 2014
												A sequel to the first FEAR which came out in '05, this game picks up almost immediatly after the first game. The 4 year gap gave FEAR 2 a chance to refresh its color scheme, giving the game a new look but keeping the same atmosphere. The game has a great visual design, definitely a step up from the bland grey theme that dominated the first game. Effects and animations are top notch and sound design is also well done. Gameplay is the typical FPS affair with various guns and enemies to shoot. The game changes things up with some turret shooting, mech fighting and a few neat set pieces. Slow mo is back and feels great as always. The story is told through in game cutscenes with good voice actors and cool effects. The plot is ok even though it can come across a ittle cheesy at some points. The haunting atmosphere is great, especially with the lights off. The only problem I can think of is the length of the game. I blew through it in a little under five hours but I was speeding through alot of the game. I didnt even read any of journals scattered throughout the levels that flesh out some backstory on whats going on. Ultimately, this is a great FPS with a effective horror theme. I could recommend this to horror fans and FPS fans alike.

content:
2015
												F.E.A.R. 2 doesn't really do anything thaaat new as an FPS.  But it does the FPS thing very well.  The main thing is how atmospheric the game is.  The combat might be relatively fast (even with the slomo powers), but the game beckons you to stop and look around once it's over.  And for such a linear game, there is always quite a bit to look at and take in.  I liked the first F.E.A.R. game because of the atmosphere and level of detail, as well.  But it suffered from a small budget.  The studio was able to make a lot more assets for F.E.A.R. 2, so the settings are much more varied.  So essentially, here, they did the thing I liked about the first game, but more.Also, the game runs really well even on ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hardware, despite how good it looks, so that's another plus.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2014
												F.E.A.R 2 improves upon the first one in many ways, with the good outweighing the bad. A main complaint is the absence of peek and lean, which is by no means a game breaker, a lesser one is that while the new weapons are extremely fun to use, they could have done a bit more innovating with this game's counterparts to the older weapons - certain are not as fun to shoot anymore. However, things like the laser and the main rifle being much more enjoyable than the rifle in F.E.A.R (assault, not the ASP) make up for it. Great pacing, narrative, production values (although still some things particularly in the sound department are inconsistent but that's something it shares with the first game). The game changes enough to offer a new experience without getting rid of the F.E.A.R feel - the largest improvement being that much of what was previously endless office buildings are now more varied and engaging. I consider this to be the final true game in the series.

												Dare I say it? Yes! This is the Half Life of this generation. This is perfection right here. Great graphics, intriguing and mysterious story, great controls, above par A.I, exceptional audio and unrivaled atmosphere. The attention to detail is astounding. Everything from graffiti to the text on little sheets of paper are clearly detailed. The environments are believable and the placement of signs and furniture are all correct. The levels are all varied and are definitely some of the best ever created. The game always feels fresh. The guns all feel unique and are quite varied. This game is now officially in the top 3 of best first person shooters ever made.Rating: PERFECT!

content:
2014
												F.E.A.R. 2 is a big step up from the first game in many ways. It provides a more cinematic look as opposed to the first game's rough, arcade style. It's considerably scarier, shifting some of its focus towards more tangible horrors and fine-tuning its brand of psychological horror. It's prettier, with high-poly models, realistic animations, and a whole range of pretty shaders. F.E.A.R. 2 is a better game than its predecessor. It's a game that has finally learned how to scare you, even if that means abandoning pure psychological horror for a more threatening approach. It's not a game riddled with jump scares either. While the slow-mo takes off some of the horror edge, encounters with the new enemies and navigating the new setpieces is very frightening.As usual, the game's plot seriously sags in the middle, but I think the only real problem with the game is that the ending is so abrupt and disappointing. There's almost no buildup, and the final fight of the game is far too easy and builds almost no tension. And then, it abruptly ends. The game itself is short, which gives the game no room for pacing aside from moving between horror bits, action bits, and story bits. In fact, aside from the very ending, there's nothing new brought to the table here, story-wise. Just some backstory you don't need to know or could have already picked up from the first game.Despite F.E.A.R. 2's lackluster plot, short length and abrupt ending, it's a good game. The combat is as fluid as ever, the game feels more broad with its increased horror and cinematics, and the visuals and sounds have been spit-shined for a nice finish. If plot isn't your thing and you just want a good, tense, shooter, then F.E.A.R. 2 will deliver that and then some.

content:
r 30, 2014
												Despite having loved the first FEAR, its sequel is a seriously mixed bag.  The weapons are fairly satisfying, although the energy weapon and laser are stupidly awkward.  Gunplay in general still feels right, but the AI lacks the level of skill and more believable squad tactics that made the gunfights in original so dynamic and enjoyable.  Things feel much more scripted now, which while not necessarily bad, certainly makes for less engaging fights overall.This almost goes without saying, but the game looks far better than the original. but it generally lacks the same unnerving tension that FEAR managed to create so regularly.  It definitely has its moments, to be sure, but it's far more sporadic.  Put differently, a lot of the scares (jump or otherwise) felt extremely formulaic at this point, with even sightings of Alma being generally unremarkable.  There were definitely some good (albeit disturbing) revelations--like the purpose of the school, or the extent of the experiments on Alma, the prototypes, and all the would-be candidates for the Program--but a lot of it still felt a bit perfunctory to me.  Maybe it's because a lot of the mystery was gone by that point.I don't want to give it away, but I found the ending totally unexpected, disturbing, but also appropriate to the kind of dark, adult story being told--particularly considering its many troublesome implications.  However, my "liking" of the ending and FEAR2 overall was also predicated on FEAR3 finally connecting all the dots in a satisfying and sufficiently harrowing way, which it most definitely did not do.  I'm seriously torn here, but I'm going to have to down-vote this one: I don't regret playing it per say, but I also can't recommend it with a straight face.  Come for the tight gunplay and lukewarm scares if you like, but if that doesn't do much for you then just play the original again and pretend that its progressively less satisfying sequels never hit store shelves.

content:
r 31, 2014
												Huge fan of the F.E.A.R series. F.E.A.R 2 is defintaly the best out of the 3. F.3.A.R was ok but strafed out of the horror segments too much and was just an all-rounder action shooter.F.E.A.R 2 has a good balance between fright and fight. Beefy accurate weapons with rate of fire options plus grenade types. The graphics are decent enough for a 2009 game and was quite demanding for PC power back in its prime. F.E.A.R 2 has outstanding animation in the enemies such as interacting with the enviroments to provide cover, dashing through windows or vaulting over ledges. Its so detailed if they set on fire near a ledge they will frail over and jump off in a panic or getting a shotgun slug to the chest, stagger back and think what the hell just hit them. Theres also the camoflague assassins that will roll around, backflip off walls and such to try and dazzle you before striking.Then theres Alma. The key character that will stalk and haunt you as you play. She seems to have techincal connections with your crosshair as where ever you look she will appear before you in rigid postions before leaping towards you.However there are things I am not happy with and thats the controls. The weapon selection can be quite messy, the ability to lean left and right from the original f.e.a.r has been taken out and also doesnt seem to be compatible with gaming mice as it only registers 2 mouse buttons which is terrible to say f.e.a.r could register 5.

content:
er 26, 2013
												 First of all compliments to the great game engine. Its shooting physics and gun play are very well done. The campaign plays just like Half-Life 2, with the story being told in the same way. Only difference is that there's random hallucinations mixed in at appropriate times. These are very well-done and although not scary, they create a great, mysterious atmosphere. The biggest disappointment is that there are no ranked multiplayer matches (2011), with only 1 or 2 unranked servers online at any given time. It's a shame since the multiplayer has potential to be fun and perhaps more polished than F.E.A.R. Combat's. The story is short with a lack of varied environments and gameplay. However, what you do get is of fairly decent quality and there's nothing like it out there. I played the demo on Xbox 360 and on PC before purchasing and it's quite clear that this game was made for the PC judging by the wealth of buttons in this game. Overall it's a decent game but not good value for money.

er 25, 2014
												FEAR 2 is a lazy, boring mess. The game's trite brand of jumpscare gorefest horror is shallow and clumsy, complementing the nonsensically stupid plot. The gameplay's not much better, with the most generic and mediocre arsenal of weaponry you can imagine scattered about yawn-inducing linear maps filled with the same enemies over and over again. Eventually the sensory overload of obnoxious sudden loud sounds and nauseating screen flashes may trigger a migraine in the player. There is nothing that FEAR 2 does that isn't done better in some other game, and even fans of the first game will find that this sequel falls short of the original in every respect.

r 16, 2014
												All the good things from FEAR 1 remain intact if slightly simplified. The fun to fight enemies are still in (they will shoot an explosive barrel if you are near one, they won't mindlessly run after you one by one, and they have great smooth movement animations), the "scary" bits are still there (I personally never thought FEAR was really that scary) and the storyline doesn't take itself too seriously. Overall, a very entertaining and functional FPS.

content:
1, 2014
												To sum it up, its a generic FPS thats based off the original but in no way recreates it or really continues the lineage of FEAR but rather takes inspiration from that game in the form of bullets on a powerpoint. Its not bad, I have played far worse but its definetly not good either.It felt like they looked at F.E.A.R. and just made a casualised/consolised version of the game instead of taking the first game and building onto that. Unfortunately it dousn't take anything that was good from the first game and build onto that and feels more like a generic FPS of these days rather than anything like the, now classic, original. The great AI is gone and feels much more basic now while they still attempt to recreate the original they feel much more stupid. The maps have alot more detail but sit at either at being simplistic places to run through or overly complicated areas where you get turned around and confused where to go. The areas though do look nice and the graphics in general are a huge jump forward in fidelity but something is lost in the transfer. The 1st game had a very flat and empty graphical design (either due to intended design or hardware limits of the time) that added towards the atmosphere which is lost with 2.  There is also alot more involvement with NPCs but unfortunately the story isn't exactly the easiest to understand or make sense at all. Honestly with this type of story there isn't much sense to be made and its more of a thriller than a story book. The scaryness isn't really there aside from a handfull of jump and other scares but its not a scary game anymore than the first and probably less so. Its mainly a shooter like the original game, but you end up fighting the same enemies over and over and scenarios reminiscent of the original game. Unfortunately the AI of the old game and feeling of a dynamic shootout escapes this one as the experience feels more canned than homemade.I would only recommend playing this if you just played FEAR and want more of that type of game or if you just want to play a generic style FPS and know what your getting into. The cinematics and writing is pretty good, but if you wanting something super serious all the way through than the writing will fail you from the very start of the game. But it tries to be serious at certain points but its hard to care about the characters in a game where the gameplay feels generic and bland. Its also very easy, for the most part you can either just blaze through areas or take advantage of faults in the AI to get past enemies more easily.Meh

content:
29, 2014
												I'm not going to waste time trying to make this post presentable, so here's a stream of consciousness (all comparisons are held against F.E.A.R. 1):Dirty dirty console port, cell shaded graphics do not fit the theme, aiming feels inaccurate, the AI is stupider, there are no graphics settings other than to change the resolution, spawn points are blatantly obvious and depressingly-purposefully annoying, the game speed is slow enough where you don't even need slo mo (fear1 is so fast you actually need it), overall it's too easy to really get into combat yet I get instakilled frequently by things I can't see (enemies spawn right behind you). FEAR1 had sprawling levels where squads could strategically engage you (or be engaged by you)- FEAR2 is all cheap spawn points in linear, uninspired level design. Ammo is dropped every two inches, it can't differentiate between left CTRL and right CTRL (fear1 could), it bugs out if you press too many keys at once (it often gets stuck strafing right, it often doesn't register keypresses, etc). Moreover the story is filled with cheap thrills and the plot is insanely stupid- they've never heard of "less is more". And the way alma is rendered is also less scary.FEAR1's plot wasn't a masterpiece by any stretch; it had some really good and unique ideas in the meat of the story, but the frame-plot / getting to the meat of the story was pretty blatantly stupid. However it was at least *paced*; seems to me like they just wanted to play with some neat horror ideas and didn't really care too much about the rest of the plot- any excuse to get the player alone in some creepy environments would do. The game is about exploring ideas, and it is about exploring Alma's backstory; clearly not a lot of effort was put into leading up to that. Knowing that the plot was largely bad, they interspersed truly intriguing elements along the way and approached the more interesting ideas *slowly*.FEAR2's approach to storytelling is to have some guy call you up and explain just about everything to you. There's no suspense or pacing. It's just... all bad.-------------------------------------F.E.A.R. 2 Reborn DLC-------------------------------------This one really builds you up just to let you down- in the beginning, things look AWESOME. Several huge issues with FEAR2 are corrected! Points in Reborn's favor:- You control a replica soldier- without slow motion abilities- with health given in numbers rather than a bar (both are good but if you have to pick one, go with numbers).- working in tandem with a squad of ally replica soldiers- with a clear, concise, simple objective that isn't stupid- You pursue enemies across sandbox like maps- no jack in the box spawn points! Enemies are actually walking around!- You are actually made vulnerable at one point; you have nothing but your firsts and you must figure out how to kill a patrol of 6-7 enemies often walking in pairs WITHOUT SLOWMO! A challenge! Well not really, there's an obviously scripted opening in which a pair split up and one of them faces his back to you long enough for you to easily kill him, grab his gun and shoot his partner. But hey, better than any given situation in all of FEAR2Then fettel gives you hallucinations in which you shoot at ghosts in self defense. When you get back to reality, you see that you have killed your squad. That is a praiseworthy mechanic and story element- or it would be if it were in a different game exploring the effects of PTSD. Here it is simply a convenient way for the game to start being complete ♥♥♥♥.Now,- you have slow mo- you have no squad, and everything that moves is your enemy- enemies spawn at stupid predefined places as usual- You are never again vulnerable / without plenty of guns to choose from- it is basically just what FEAR2 was likeQuite disappointing. And alma was in her child form again for some reason, trying to kill you. OK, what? To both points. Why is she a kid again suddenly? Why is she trying to kill you? Why does fettel have you kill your squad rather than just instruct everyone that you're going on a solo mission for a bit? He is a ♥♥♥♥ing commander of the entire replica army after all. Why is alma preventing you, both personally and by way of ordering replicas to kill you, from reviving her dead son? Her son who spent the entirety of the previous game trying to set her free?This is really just a jumble of plot points shoved together with minimal effort, providing absolutely nothing new. It's just FEAR2 recycled in no particularly interesting way, and a deliberate "we want more money!" DLC.

												this game...this game was so so so so disappointing to be fair to anyone who reads this im just going to flag this all as a spoiler cause it's that bad. I really wanted to like this game, i really wanted to like the fear series but the promises and expectations this game promised are commmmmmmmplete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. First off this game should not be called FEAR, it should be called "scripted events you wont notice but we will make your HUD twitch to tell you it is happening". Also the smart UI of NPCs is complete trash and it doesn't become more difficult when the damn NPCs continue to ANNOUNCE WHAT THEY ARE DOING "gernade out!" WELL I GUESS I WILL MOVE. The story is so thin and tries to give back story to Alma by sending you to her elementary school and trying to showcase how she is a victim of the experiments on her and she was just different. And yeah thats fine i guess if you just showed me like a short cinematic that detailed this instead of making me walk through repetative buildings and terrible outdated combat scenarios i would have appreciated that.but the finale... after everything that game made me walk through the ending wasn't just terrible it was kind of offensive.You get ♥♥♥♥♥ by the ghost of Alma, yup it happens she ties you down to a chair and induces halucinations on you and inbetween the final fight you see flashing cut scenes of her riding you and after the fight she appears before you magical pregnant. after seeing that I was done with the series and have made a promise to never play another FEAR.

The first real sequel to the original F.E.A.R.

Great gameplay/graphics, better characters and storyline although not as scary.
Very difficult enemies like before, with new boss battles which are extremely challenging, SO challenging that it ruins it F*CKING GAME!

You get more weapons to choose from, and finally able to aim down the sights for better accuracy.

The story does the typical scenario(s) where you spend so much time meeting up with your teammates, only to be separated again by random sh*t occuring, then repeat.

Very gorey, and would highly recommend if you like the original F.E.A.R. game!

6/10

er 26, 2013
												This is a surprisingly good shooter. It's got the old school health and armor system but there are always health and armor pickups in plain sight between firefights so you never have to backtrack to find more health. The weapons are really nice. You can hold 4 weapons so you can pretty much grab whatever is lying around and not worry about being poorly equipped for the next part and there are only really 1 or 2 weapons that suck and not worth grabbing. Enemies always drop plenty of ammo so you can just fire away. One thing that makes this game stand out gameplay wise is the slow-motion ability. It feels really nice to use, looks cool and helps to stop the game from feeling like a generic shooter. Then there are the spooky parts. While not necessarily scary they do really add to the environment of the game. The game looks very good at max settings and is very well detailed and surprisingly full of colour. While it doesn't massively deviate from the standard shooter genre at the time it shows that shooters can still be different and fun. I give it 4 brain aneurysms out of 5.

content:
y 29, 2012
												Making sequels is a gamble. You have, on one hand, an opportunity learn from your mistakes and make this an even better game. On the other hand, you might unknowingly alienate fans with unnecessary additions. Sadly, it is within the latter category that Project Origin sits.F.E.A.R. (the original) is a great game and to improve upon it is no easy task. It boasts a tense atmosphere made all the better by its excellent artificial intelligence. One would expect the sequel to build upon, if not at least around, what made its predecessor great. Project Origin instead bolts the other way.Keeping F.E.A.R's weak story and generic gunplay, Project Origin is even less frightening. The fantastic pacing is now replaced with frequent jolts of action sequences. But most unforgivable of all, is the dumbing down of the A.I.Maybe I've become too familiar with the nuances of F.E.A.R.'s computer controlled enemies. Regardless, Project Origin offers neither challenge nor robust campaign.Grade: B-

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2011
												I saw comments saying this was distinctly lower quality than the original game and its expansions, but I personally found FEAR 2 to be much more fun than the first and it provided a fairly diverse gaming experience in terms of varied locations, a more healthy selection of enemy types (though still largely clones and mercs), and the plot was far more interesting, even a little spine tingling. The level designs featured rich detail and I appreciated that both objectives and exits were more clearly defined. The makers also kept things from getting overly repetitive by staggering sequences where you use Avatar-like power armor and arenas where you're forced to use your sniping skills. However, the character dialogue was stilted and crammed with poorly utilized profanity, and you have no means to alter the progression of events. In the end, I thought it was a mixed bag much like the original, but still a genuinely entertaining experience and with some very impressive visual flourishes.

content:
er 21, 2015
												Fear 2: Project Origin tells the story of psychic soldiers, crazy little girls, secrets and coverups. There are some cutscenes and readable backstory but seriously, that's not why we are here. We are here for some good old ultra violence. So let's look into that.The game tries to be cinematic with it's slow-mo combat but now in the year 2015 it fails. The effects that maybe once were cutting edge are now average at best. To get as much sparks in the air as possible there needs to be a lot of bullets flying and what this means is that all weapons are horribly inaccurate and ineffective. Single headshot with assault rifle does nothing, you need 2-3. Spraying at a distance of say 15 meters you can be sure that you need atleast 20-30 smg rounds to kill an enemy. The sniper rifle is the players best friend even indoors.Project Origin is new enough to have physics modeling but it basically only applies to corpses. Throw a grenade into an office full of desks, books etc. and very little moves. So no redeeming factors there either. Bullet spongy enemies without a proper fireworks display gets old fast. The game has few sections where the player gets to pilot a mech and in those you can destroy a decent amount of the scenery. Why it's restricted only to these levels is beyond me.What suprised me most though was how powerless the sound design is. The weapon sounds and explosions are really weak. The design is also weird: For example if you stand next to and look at something that makes noise (machine, person talking, burning corpse etc.) you hear the sound it makes. Turn 180 and the sound almost disappears. Face the object again and it returns. When that is added to the lackluster visuals there really isn't much for the senses. Needless to say, on a modern machine Fear 2 runs without problems. On top of that it does have a wide range of graphical options to choose from.Fear in this game translates into jump scares and they really are not scary. Some of the most gory parts are ghastly but there is no sense of threat. It's just blood and gore. Levels are made of grey facilities or ruins of a city so no wild set design here. At one part of the game the player has to navigate through a literal monster closet factory which was just silly. Fortunately the AI is really aggressive and they will run after the player like bloodhounds and throw grenades like they have boxes full of them on hand. Only problem is that they tend to come at you one or two at a time so it's rarely overwhelming. On the hardest difficulty the player character dies really easily which is a good thing but it only emphasizes the fact that similarily equiped enemies can take bullets like rain.In todays market, where there are loads of games available and a lot on sale at all times, you can do much better than Fear 2: Project origin. The first F.E.A.R might have some value as a classic or a game that pushed the genre forward and maybe should be played for that reason. This second installment doesn't even have that quality. It's not unplayable or anything, it just doesn't have much to offer anymore.

content:
y 19, 2011
												Scary as all hell game. Replayability value, too! Not much to say, really, your average FPS, run around, shoot, lean around corners, regular movement is all there. No crawl or creep, however, just crouch. Kinda boring, right? Well... no. This game has all kinds of screwed up ♥♥♥♥ to keep you entertained. You spend much of it witnessing screwed up ♥♥♥♥ happening, or seeing the 'after' side of the picture. Want to nail army guys to walls? You can do that. Want to set them on fire, THEN nail them to walls? That too. Or just blow them apart with shotguns? Oh hell yes. The combat never gets boring. Grenades are good, too, with a very handy five-count GUI. There's a nice amount of different types, too, for an FPS. Standard frag, then shock, then incendiary. I do think there is stun, too, but can't remember. The story is awesome too! Like piecing a puzzle together.Pros-Looks amazing-Plays amazing-Scary!-Storyline win!Cons-Short-Alma-Not much atmosphere-Uh... Alma?

number of helpful: 8 of 19 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
17
												Dear F.E.A.R 2, Thank you for setting 2 steps backwards in terms of AI and gameplay in comparison to your predecessor: F.E.A.R. The removal of peeking makes the gameplay feels dull and forces me to use slomo in such an excellent way, because the only reason why I would ever need to use slomo is due to the fact I am now forced to be unable to peek from corners. Not because I don't want to, but because apparently it was decided that slomo and corner peeking can't coexist, or I will be inevitably overpowered in the game. Slomo! Anyone? AI's are significantly dumber and scripted, have ridiculously little amount of health, and worse accuracy compared with in FEAR, making those especially with power suit and yellow facial plates look like bulky paper dolls. (and to add to the drama, they explode upon being shot at and blast into pieces.. is that normal?) Even on hard difficulty, in quite amount of situations where I have sufficient cover, it is still very doable to take out the whole AI squat standing kinda in the open without using slomo (can't peek now remember?), making the game feels awkwardly imbalanced and the combat becomes amature and boring because I simply couldn't peek from corners while AI's can - the only thing that makes them seem more intelligent than me in this game. And the guns -- where is the recoil? It makes the shooing feel so plastic and unrealistic with low recoil compared to weapons in FEAR. If FEAR was a pure experience of pleasurable shooter with excellent combat system and AI designs, F.E.A.R 2 is but a bland sequel that takes away most of that pleasure from the previous FEAR in exchange for brilliant ideas such as story log which I can pick up from the game and checking them out by pressing the Tab key accompanied by the euphonic sound in the background consist of the annoying static-sounding beep.Also, many thanks to the try-hard-but-failed scary scenes that mistook the concept of gore with fear. Surely I might fear the gory content, but that should not be where the scare lies. FEAR delivered a better and deeper psychological fear while here in F.E.A.R 2, it's being considerably reduced to the very superficial. Appreciate that. The saddest part, was that the in game music is so original but doesn't feel the same anymore much thanks to such downgrades mentioned above.. Sincerely, Me. If you, someone who reads this right now, own F.E.A.R, let the glory stays with it because that's where the fun is gonna be. Don't bother with this one. It could still be a decent shooter to you if you haven't played FEAR, but certainly not those who did, unfortunately. 2.5h is already a complement, any more than that i shall feel sorry for not using the time to play FEAR instead. You might argue that the lack of peek function is but a different focus the game decide to have, however, to FEAR's own standard, this is unacceptable and a huge shame.

content:
er 8, 2014
												FEAR 2 is the sequel to FEAR (obviously). You play as a Delta Force soldier named Michael Beckett who is sent to capture Armacham (the bad guys from 1) president.There are some dramatic gameplay changes from the 1st game, and they are all absolutely terrible. No more awesome gunfights with smart AI. Now you just fight waves of dumb enemies. AI is really inconsistent. They go from not even noticing you after you've shot two of their team mates in the same room and circling around a grenade you've just thrown to having the reactions of someone who just snorted crack and with aimbotting accuracy. I will also note they have serious trouble throwing grenades.Another change was the removal of peak buttons. This wouldn't ♥♥♥♥ me off so much if this game actually gave you a reasonable amount of health but instead you are forced to hide by corners and pick enemies off. No more running into rooms with slow-motion on. Try that and you better hope you kill all enemies before slow mo runs out. If I really need to manipulate cover, I need more than a press E to flip over a ♥♥♥♥ing table here.To begin with the guns all feel incredibly useless. The SMG sounds okay at best, and the pistol sounds like it's less useful than harsh language. The combat shotgun's sound is laughable and pathetic. Even some of the better weapons like the assault rifle, (semi) automatic shotgun and sniper rifle don't feel extremely powerful. There aren't many new weapons. Most of them are re-skins. Only new are the automatic shotgun, sniper rifle and laser gun which are somewhat welcome additions.The one thing I thought could save the game was the sections where you get to pilot a mech, but some idiot decided that there should be some grainly filter over the screen that gets even worse as you take damage. It absolutely looked horrible and I found it incredible distracting.About the only thing improved from the original game is the fact that there are more varied environments for levels, but that's nothing if I'm not enjoying the time spent in said environments.All in all the gameplay felt like a cookie cutter shooter which needed to give the player one or two more health packs and armour pickups (at least on hard).Story wise this game is kinda like the first. It gets very predictable, especially if you've played the first game. The scares are the same, although I did feel this game was a little more scary than the first, it still failed to terrify me. Most of the jumpscares were fairly predictable, and there was only so many times that seeing Alma and bloody rooms could be even somewhat unsettling.All in all, I'd advise you play the first FEAR game. It runs rings around this game. If you need something else to hit that slow-motion Hollywood badass fix go check out the Max Payne series. The only reason I could possibly recommend this game is if you've played the first FEAR and wish to see how the story plays out.4/10

content:
4, 2016
												FEAR 1, simply put, is one of my favorite shooters, not necessarily because of great level design or compelling encounter design, but rather the feel of the combat is phenomenal. FEAR 1 felt like an explosive orgy of boom-booms and men turning into paste while losing limbs and screaming out in agony and fear.So yeah, it was popping off.FEAR 2, in comparison, is a very limp donger, it is a sodden ♥♥♥♥, it is a miserable experience.The first thing you'll notice is the blinding bloom, a lot of people act like FEAR 2 is graphically better than FEAR 3, but I don't think an obnoxious lighting engine that blasts primary colors into your face is "good graphics." It follows the late 00s trend of using fierce bloom and excessive colored lighting to hide the fact that the models and textures are mediocre pap.The combat feels lose and weak, while FEAR 1 was a little clunky in its heaviness, and FEAR 2 certainly feels more snappy, you're switching out meaty, impactful combat for what feels like little pop guns weakly penetrating fleshy enemies that seem to melt like popsicles when they're dismembered, rather than the brutal mutilations in the original game.Guns are quiet and feel like mush, enemies glow for some strange reason (enemies weren't difficult to find in FEAR 1, and FEAR 3 does fine without the glowing as well, I don't understand the reasoning for this mechanic) and even though they maintain the aggression of the AI from the original game, they're just less effective, they don't hurt as much, they don't really feel like a real threat, and the enemy variety is still crap.While enemies will now tumble over cover and are generally mobile, they just don't feel satisfying to fight, everyone has some kind of pathetic nerd voice compared to the rumbling, distorted communications in the original game, and the voice acting for them is just flat, it's just not as fun hearing them freak out like it was in the first game.They also took out the lean function, and instead replaced it with the ability to flip over cover, but it's rather pointless, there's absolutely no reason to use cover in this game, enemies hit like hotdogs smacking your face so most of the time you just slo-mo (and by the way the meter is absolutely tiny, even with the reflex boosters, compared to the first game) and headshot, that's it, there's even less reason to use grenades in this game than the last.The absolute biggest disappointments are the shotguns. In FEAR 1 it was easily the most satisfying weapon, here they can't hit worth a damn, do absolutely no damage when they do impact, and feel like someone is mushing ground beef through a sausage maker. What is this weak nonsense?I can go on about the idiotic story, the worthless characters, the annoying melee enemies that add absolutely nothing to the game resembling fun, crappy boss encounters that aren't entertaining in the least, and repeating, samey levels that are either massacres of bloom or dark and dingey crap. FEAR 1 didn't have the greatest environmental design, but I expect a greater improvement than spattering color everywhere.The elementary school is alright, but that's about it.Even the linear mech segments suck and feel unsatisfying, because the weapons for those blow too, the enemies look goofy instead of cool as they did before (what happened to the sweet heavies with the insect eyes from the first game), and the dismemberment is super lame and reminds me of Fallout 3 where body parts just seem to glide off like enemies are made out of wet newspaper.This game is mediocre beyond belief, everything about it is an exercise in misery, it's too easy, feels weak, looks like a complete mess that just wants to stab your eyes with bright lights, sounds like crap, plays like crap, what the hell went wrong?If you can get through it all, somehow, it casts a magical spell on you, basically making you forget everything that happened in the last craptastic 6 hours, since there's literally nothing worth remembering in this absolute turd of a game. Hell, I only recall vaguely being angry at a certain unfun part of the game, and I can't even place it now. I usually remember things that ♥♥♥♥ me off very, very well, but FEAR 2 is such a powerful wizard it somehow even manages to wipe clean whatever atrocity it committed upon me.Even FEAR 3 is better than this abysmal excuse for a game, avoid this junk.

content:
er 25, 2013
												I wanted to like F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin.  I really did.  As a fan of the original game, I was equal parts relieved and excited at the news of Monolith’s re-acquisition of the F.E.A.R. license.  The masters had recovered their legacy, and I couldn’t wait to welcome Alma back into my nightmares again.  Unfortunately, after finishing F.E.A.R. 2, it became disappointingly apparent to me that in the time between Monolith’s loss and recovery of the F.E.A.R. IP, they forgot what made the original game a genre-defining game, as they have led its sequel into potential-dashing mediocrity.   Immediately, players are introduced to the new player character, Michael Beckett (A.K.A. “Bucket.”  Seriously.), whom we quickly discover that Alma kind of has a thing for…apparently.  But more on that later.  The mainstay of F.E.A.R. 2’s gameplay is the series’ standout action elements, returning in all their bloody, hyper-reflexive glory.  Sporting smooth, polished gunplay and the return of F.E.A.R.’s standout enemy A.I., F.E.A.R. 2’s gunfights will rarely leave players wanting.  The welcome addition of several new enemy types, new combat mechanics, and the inclusion of a few mech-combat sequences help to keep combat fresh, but have a tendency to completely distract players from any semblance of horror for fairly lengthy intervals.  Complementing these features are modernized visuals and several welcome deviations from the series’ previously monotonous environments. Certain set-pieces, especially the series’ hallmark hallucinations, are surprisingly well-composed, lending F.E.A.R. 2’s presentation a certain degree of artistry.  These features notwithstanding, it should be noted however, that while F.E.A.R. 2’s graphics and level design far surpass those of its predecessor, they only just meet the par of its contemporaries, and the same can be said for the game’s decidedly sub-par multiplayer.  Having established those things, I feel like I’ve written the rest of this review before.  Namely, Monolith has made a lot of the same mistakes with F.E.A.R. 2 that Timgate Studios made with the Perseus Mandate expansion pack before it.  From the odd choice of departing from the original game’s art style to F.E.A.R. 2’s nonsensical story, the game just doesn’t really feel like a F.E.A.R. sequel, in appearance or spirit.Relying more upon jump-scares than psychological dread, F.E.A.R. 2’s horror segments are more nerve-wracking than they are unsettling, and this trend infects the story as a whole.  Its departure from Point Man aside, the game doesn’t even seem to remember its own timeline throughout its disjointedly illogical narrative, and many of Alma’s actions throughout the game just come off as arbitrarily forced.   She has no reason, especially early on, to take notice of Beckett, and yet she harries, attacks, and molests him like something out of Navi’s darkest nightmares, keeping many of the game’s would-be horror sequences from feeling more than marginally threatening, and instead lending them an unwelcome atmosphere of uncomfortability.  Seriously, there are segments of this game that are just plain unpleasant to sit through, especially its “twist” ending, which really robs players of any sense of climactic achievement.As an FPS, F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin is a bloody good time, but as a horror game, much less a proper F.E.A.R. sequel, it falls disappointingly short.  Despite its solid action, its neutered horror and vague, paranormally hormonal storyline bar it from living up to its legacy, and its replay value is middling at best after single-player’s completion.  I can’t say that recommendations come easily for it, especially for fans of F.E.A.R., but FPS junkies like myself may enjoy this momentarily dark departure from the usual fare of run n’ gun action.Rating: 5.8Visuals: 6Audio: 5Controls & Mechanics: 7Atmosphere & Experience: 6Entertainment Value: 5For more reviews, articles, and videos, visit LastLevelPress.com!

content:
y 20, 2014
												A shooter that simply ticks all generic shooter boxes.  Dimly lit corridors? check.  Warehouse/crates? check.  BOO! check,  bullet-time? check, Explodey tanks lying around waiting for you to make them go boom, crawlspaces? check! and let's not forget the bit where you're on a train and baddies keep coming at you from another track... etcEnvironments: Corridors, do you like dimly lit corridors?  I hope you do.  You might be lucky and get some warehouse/crate action!!!  You get released from the tiny outdoor areas a few, all to brief times, then it's back to corridors and subway tunnels (yes, we're back to subway tunnels etc).  There are some better zones later on, big factory settings that at least have some sense of scale, but you wait a long time for them.Shooty Bang Bang: The guns work, not much interest, the assault rifle is pretty much the entire game.  The hammerhead is nice, but no other weapon than assault rifle is necessary for 99% of the game.  Shotguns are cool for the things that charge you like abominations and assassins, but assault rifle is fine for them too.  Weapons that might provide some variety are castrated by lack of ammo.Tank bits are fun, of course, tank bits are always fun.The Story: Spooky bits are pretty much eye candy, there's no serious effect on the game, it's a straightforward shooty game with gratuituous spooky effects seemingly tagged on at the last minute to remind you that this is a FEAR game. Yes it does make you jump from time to time, effective in the same way as a screamer video on YouTube.   The levels are strewed with pointless info drops, saves having to script an interesting game I guess, having your plot all scrawled down on little data pads.  Ignore them. Enemy AI: basic stuff.   You walk along, the game will auto-save to let you know there's a firefight coming, creep, crouch, bullet-time headshot them till they're all dead. rinse-repeat... in corridors.The Ending:  Was that an ending? Ummm. ok...  I guess this was an Episode of something...Overall: Meh, dull, unimaginative, fails to make any use of the IP.

												F.E.A.R. 2 is an average FPS with poor horror elements that could've been a lot better. Overall, it's not a terrible game by any means, however, I found it boring and couldn't finish the storyline as it had many issues: annoying and ugly frame-like HUD; high sensitivity without an option to adjust it; rather funny sprinting mechanics; highly repetitive combat; some fire particles were often stuck on my screen; giant robots ignored me sometimes; story so far was below average; dialogue seemed to be fanmade, etc.. Despite these flaws the level design wasn't as bad as I thought it'll be and even the repetitive combat had some fun moments that kept me interested for a couple hours. Nevertheless, I wouldn't recommend buying it.A weak 5/10

												I have a reasonably modern system (6-core Intel, Radeon R9 270, 64GB RAM, SSD), and the game simply will not start correctly.It displays the "detecting system performance" screen, then goes black and minimizes.  Clicking the taskbar icon causes it to restore and immediately re-minimize.  If I close the app, then every run afterward is the same, although the "detecting system performance" screen is omitted.Since there are no log files and there is nothing documenting the one very small text config file, and any changes to it are immediately reverted when the game is run again, I have no hint as to what went wrong.Luckily, I bought the game on a great sale.

content:
6, 2013
												Many claim that this game shouldn't bear the name of FEAR, but no, since the two games are quite similar.There are enemies that come from very limited entrances, and you just slow down the time to shoot their heads until they become ragdolls every time... nothing has changed. Also, the unnecessary amount of variations for grenades and very poorly written story (or, lack thereof) is in this game, too.That aforementioned many also say that this game lacks the fear factor that the first game has. It is an undeniable truth that this is not a good horror game, but the first game isn't, too. Voice of the many bashes this game for only having jump scares, but the first one does, too.Vox populi is also that this game should be cleansed with the righteous fire of PC gamers because this game doesn't have the ability to lean, which the first one has. While it is obvious that the feature is removed for the sake of making the game for consoles along with PC, that feature is completely irrelevant to the first game, to begin with. There is simply no need for leaning, and it isn't even realistic, as nobody trained properly would peek-and-shoot from covers while making entries in as close quarter engagements as the two games depict. There are very few areas that call for leaning in both games, but they are too rare to warrant implementing it.This is FEAR 2, a sequel to that mindless shooter. It's good for what it is.

ry 27
												Like the first FEAR game, FEAR 2 was slapped around when it came out, ironically, for not being a replica of the first game. The main complaint was the watered-down melee system, which didn't matter to me, because I play first-person-shooters to shoot stuff, not punch stuff. What really bothered me was the weak story.But I got over it.All you need to know is that this game is made by Monolith. MONOLITH. These are the same people who gave us BLOOD, the best first-person-shooter ever made. Monolith is one in the trifecta of FPS giants: Id, Raven, and Monolith. Nobody makes shooters better than these three.Sure, I could go on a lengthy tirade about how the graphics have aged beautifully, the slow-mo gunplay is amazing, the level design is fantastic, the weapon animations are breathtakingly gorgeous, the enemies are compelling, the art assets are top notch, the story is basically a rehash of the first game with a twist at the end, the mech sequences completely crash the flow, and the elementary school level is scary as ♥♥♥♥... But all you really need to know is that it's a Monolith game.

content:
10
												After playing F.E.A.R. and its non-canon expansion packs, I was stoked to play sequel to the amazing original. After having played it... I had a lot of fun with the sequel, but I felt that several things were inferior to the first game. Nonetheless, this is a solid game and I would still recommend playing it. I'm gonna talk about the pros first, cons next and lastly sum up my review.First positive and for me the most notable: the visuals. This game is beautiful. Even for its time in 2009 its graphics still hold up pretty well, especially in comparison to the now very dated look of the first game. Additionally, most locations in the game have a much prettier and vibrant color palette varying from light blues, to orange, to red. Definitely a much more colorful game in comparison to F.E.A.R..Secondly the action of this game was greatly improved. The first game had a tendency to be laggy during intense firefights or boss fights, and the overall combat was a little choppy. The sequel definitely made the firefights much smoother to improve the combat. I have but one complaint about the changes made to combat in F.E.A.R. 2 but I will cover that in a sec. They added a hit indicator when you are firing so it's easier to tell if you score a hit on an enemy, weapons now have the option of an alternate firing mode, you are able to interact with your environment to flip certain forms of cover to aid you in your fight, and the added variety of weapons and special grenades that you can cook to delay the explosion really improve the gameplay. My major complaint about F.E.A.R. 2 is the removal of the lean mechanic in the first game. It makes using corners less effective and instead wants to emphasize the usage of flipping cover instead.These are the two major positives for the game, now for the negatives..Much like the first game, having a silent protagonist works in certain games if the surrounding cast are able to fill in the gaps of dialogue. But a complaint of mine is the lack of any character arcs in the game. Every character introduced is the same when the game begins to when the game ends save for one. While this isn't as major a problem in games as in film it does make the game feel a little repetitive when the characters don't experience any changes aside of a short period of a breakdown after losing a comrade or something of the like.Secondly is the blend of horror and action. I feel this game fell to a similar fate of Dead Space 3, as action is more focused than actual horror. While still definitely scary and creepy as hell at certain moments, action definitely takes a greater hold in this title.Last is the story/ending. While fairly straight-forward and competent the story doesn't necessarily raise many questions during the gameplay, and it overall doesn't make a whole lot of sense while you start to learn more about what is going on, most notably in the character motivations on both sides. But I'm not gonna lie the ending of this game actually made me laugh. No spoilers, but the ending while somewhat intriguing and raising some questions such as my own reaction "Did that just really happen?", is just executed poorly and it felt silly what actually happened to end the game. While the answers are brought up again in the following game F.E.A.R. 3, it doesn't necessarily  have the effectiveness of the cliffhanger ending of the first game.Overally this game is a very fun, kick-♥♥♥ shooter with some spooky-♥♥♥ moments, but the story, characters and horror elements I feel definitely faltered in comparison to the original.I'll give it a 7.5/10.

content:
2, 2013
												I played the first FEAR game when it came out in 2005. It was actually one of the last games I preordered it and enjoyed it. Eight years later I finally got around to playing FEAR 2. So what did I think? Overall it wasn't a BAD experience. But there are some BAD things in the game I can mention. I remember the AI in the first FEAR game to be pretty good. Enemies would flank, take cover, etc. In this game they take cover but they'll also run right into the line of fire and do other assorted stupid things. The guns felt really, REALLY underpowered. One enemy took five shots from a shotgun before dying. Really? Oh, another piece of advice, ditch the pistol when you can. POS. Mission variety wasn't there. It was pretty much go to point A to point B and kill ♥♥♥♥ in between. You can walk around in a mech suit and get behind a large machinegun. That was as varied as it got.  There were some good things though. Level design was improved quite a bit. Instead of running around through office building after office building in the first FEAR game, you actually get some different environments. Special nod to the school map in this game, which I liked quite a bit.  The atmosphere was nice even with the obvious jump scares etc. There was a nice variety of weapons and the laser in particular was fun AND effective. The story was okay I guess. Thankfully you didn't have to memorize the first to enjoy this one. Oh, and the file size for the game is 12 GB which seems pretty damn huge for what's here but that's a minor gripe. Overall FEAR 2 gets a recommendation from me. You should be able to get it pretty cheap with the FEAR Trilogy pack during a summer/winter sale. Wait until then. 7/10 for FEAR 2 from me.

												F.E.A.R. 2 takes place around the same time as F.E.A.R. but played by another protagonist named Beckett. The game no longer allows you to save whenever you want, it uses checkpoints but it makes these at frequent spots so it doesn't get frustrating at all. It introduces great new weapons and at some points you will even pilot a mech.The storyflow, plot development and character interaction is also well done. It makes you feel you're in a real world where you will care what happens to all the NPC you interact with.FEAR 2 - Reborn.In this short add-on you play as a replica clone soldier named Foxtrot 813 who for a mysterious reason is drawn by the ghost of Fettel from the first F.E.A.R. game. The story won't make much sense until the very end. But after playing F.E.A.R. 3, this I have doubts if this story is canon at all. It doesn't fit with F.E.A.R. 3 at all and I blame that game's very poor story for it (read my review there).

content:
1, 2014
												The refined sequel to what is already a bit of a modern classic, F.E.A.R. F.E.A.R. 2 improves on everything and as a result, plays much more smoothly than its somewhat clunky predecessor.Graphics are crisp and clear, comparable to Max Payne 2, which means they are still holding up rather well today.Sound is excellent, much better than the first installment. In particular, the score has seen notable improvement.Gameplay still rewards a tactical approach to combat, though you no longer depend on your slow-motion ability quite as much as you used to in F.E.A.R. Gunfight are often winnable even without resorting to slow-motion, though using it definitely helps.F.E.A.R. 2 provides the same type of scares as the first game, so they may sometimes be fairly cheap. Due to the improved visual fidelity, the gore is much more explicite here, however. This game is not for the squeamish.Any shooter fan should definitely pick this up, even if they didn't like or play the first installment.

content:
, 2014
												This game was a lot shorter than I remember. It's seven chapters long, and follows a pretty strict formula.>battle soliders>creepy ♥♥♥♥>some ghosts>battle soldiers>story progressionthat's pretty much it. you'll know when you're fighting ghosts because the color will drain from your screen and ♥♥♥♥ will get dumb.compared to F.E.A.R. 1, this game doesn't really hold a candle to it. The AI in this game is worse, you can't lean, the flashlight illuminates less (which may be intentional), there is no battery for the flashlight (it's infinite), and there's a lot more run and gun than F.E.A.R. 1. The enemies take a ♥♥♥♥ ton of bullets to kill.Oh yeah, and there's no VK-12 shotgun. The ending was a great porno. Multiplayer is dead too, so if you were looking for that, don't bother.Overall, the game gets a 3/5. It's an average shooter with above average graphics (for it's time), interesting story, and good sound.It doesn't beat the original F.E.A.R. though.

I'll start by saying DON'T WAST YOUR MONEY!!!!!Monolith Productions have completely destroyed a great game by turning their backs on what made F.E.A.R a great game you will find that the AI no longer works against you and anticipates your moves before you could hear the squad commander say "Flush Him Out!" and another clone would throw a grenade at you to make you move from cover now they don't they just stand in the open firing clip after clip after clip hoping to hit you there is a few occasions where a clone will move something to hide behind but rather getting the rest of the squad to pin the player with suppressing fire or firing his gun over the top or from the side they stand up and shoot making them easy to hit along the same lines when you encountered a clone in the original F.E.A.R if on there on would fall back and find backup before taking the player on but not in F.E.A.R 2 they have lost their sense of danger and mortality I am very disappointed with this game and that is why I rate this game 3/10 a very poor performance Monolith Productions very poor.

content:
2012
												Somehow even LESS thematic than the original, despite improved graphics.  Only one or two scenes had good setting and feel.  Enemies seem a little less smart than the previous, although they dont get murdered by their inability to use doors this time.  They're just more aggressive about pushing forward and not making footsteps when they do.  Fairly easy on Normal, nothing felt very hard to kill.  Horror segments are quite nonthreatening, but the use of light phantasms compared to the previous game's dark phantasms was a great choice that I loved.Instead of answering people's voicemail, this time you read their dropped memos.  People are pretty darn clumsy when it comes to dropping important memos.Game ran well on a Phenom II x6 / HD 6850, no hiccups.  8hrs of gameplay total for campaign + DLC.  Did not try multiplayer.

y 31, 2016
												F.E.A.R. 2 Pro-----New GUI but intrusive but overall ok , graphics have been updated- more detailed environment and weapons have been reskinned, Have iron sights. Favorite level was in school, can cook grenades- but grenades seem to have strange psychics; always thrown in front or behind enemies. You can create cover by contact sensitive pushing over tables or furniture-but hardly ever used it. Mech combat and turret sections is cool but only happens twice eachCons-------Game is un-optimized, framerate is inconsistent. Hade to play on lowest setting to get it to run constantly but still dripped in frames Shotgun is really underpowered also pistol is weak. Hardly ever used Slow-Mo, Story made little sense. Enemy AI is still decent but fells like a downgrade. No more tilt mechanic. No Quick save, overall feels distant from original. Little enemy variety and levels are the same reused.More wave based encounters but still fight squads. Ghost are annoying to fight, horror is not scary; jump scares and this enemy who used dead enemies to fight for it is annoying to fight, bullet sponged. Melee is weak. Overall not so original and feels like other games.

content:
ry 6, 2016
												I was always interested in the sequels to Fear, and this, although not as great as Fear 1, was good. I felt it was the Opposing Force to Half-Life, as this is in the same universe, but follows a different character.Graphics:- The graphics were decent, but the colours are strange. Like watching an old cathode ray television with just a slight misalignment to slignal. A very thin veil of snowy vision.Sounds:- Sound effects were great, but music was misplaced. Obviously cued based on when you enter certain areas, but sometimes it would kick off or rev up AFTER a fire-fight had ended.Gameplay:- You can feel this was made for a console. Which sucks, because Fear 1 was such a great PC game. But, I had so many fantastic scares right off the bat. This game scared me, and made me really carefully play a lot more than Fear 1.- It's a longer game than the original and took me 5hrs longer to complete than Fear 1. But I did play on the hardest difficult which probably added some additional time and strategy to my decisions.Story:- Great story, very intriguing. I good addition to the FEAR universe and forms the foundation of Fear 3 (although, Fear 3 is not as good).

												After playing F.E.A.R. and its non-canon expansion packs, I was stoked to play sequel to the amazing original. After having played it... I had a lot of fun with the sequel, but I felt that several things were inferior to the first game. Nonetheless, this is a solid game and I would still recommend playing it. I'm gonna talk about the pros first, cons next and lastly sum up my review.First positive and for me the most notable: the visuals. This game is beautiful. Even for its time in 2009 its graphics still hold up pretty well, especially in comparison to the now very dated look of the first game. Additionally, most locations in the game have a much prettier and vibrant color palette varying from light blues, to orange, to red. Definitely a much more colorful game in comparison to F.E.A.R..Secondly the action of this game was greatly improved. The first game had a tendency to be laggy during intense firefights or boss fights, and the overall combat was a little choppy. The sequel definitely made the firefights much smoother to improve the combat. I have but one complaint about the changes made to combat in F.E.A.R. 2 but I will cover that in a sec. They added a hit indicator when you are firing so it's easier to tell if you score a hit on an enemy, weapons now have the option of an alternate firing mode, you are able to interact with your environment to flip certain forms of cover to aid you in your fight, and the added variety of weapons and special grenades that you can cook to delay the explosion really improve the gameplay. My major complaint about F.E.A.R. 2 is the removal of the lean mechanic in the first game. It makes using corners less effective and instead wants to emphasize the usage of flipping cover instead.These are the two major positives for the game, now for the negatives..Much like the first game, having a silent protagonist works in certain games if the surrounding cast are able to fill in the gaps of dialogue. But a complaint of mine is the lack of any character arcs in the game. Every character introduced is the same when the game begins to when the game ends save for one. While this isn't as major a problem in games as in film it does make the game feel a little repetitive when the characters don't experience any changes aside of a short period of a breakdown after losing a comrade or something of the like.Secondly is the blend of horror and action. I feel this game fell to a similar fate of Dead Space 3, as action is more focused than actual horror. While still definitely scary and creepy as hell at certain moments, action definitely takes a greater hold in this title.Last is the story/ending. While fairly straight-forward and competent the story doesn't necessarily raise many questions during the gameplay, and it overall doesn't make a whole lot of sense while you start to learn more about what is going on, most notably in the character motivations on both sides. But I'm not gonna lie the ending of this game actually made me laugh. No spoilers, but the ending while somewhat intriguing and raising some questions such as my own reaction "Did that just really happen?", is just executed poorly and it felt silly what actually happened to end the game. While the answers are brought up again in the following game F.E.A.R. 3, it doesn't necessarily  have the effectiveness of the cliffhanger ending of the first game.Overally this game is a very fun, kick-♥♥♥ shooter with some spooky-♥♥♥ moments, but the story, characters and horror elements I feel definitely faltered in comparison to the original.I'll give it a 7.5/10.
